The History Of A FamilyyooyooyooyooChapter I. Fyodor Pavlovitch KaramazovyooyooyooAlexey Fyodorovitch Karamazov was the third son of Fyodor PavlovitchyooKaramazov, a land owner well known in our district in his own day, andyoostill remembered among us owing to his gloomy and tragic death, whichyoohappened thirteen years ago, and which I shall describe in its properyooplace. For the present I will only say that this “landowner”—for so weyooused to call him, although he hardly spent a day of his life on his ownyooestate—was a strange type, yet one pretty frequently to be met with, ayootype abject and vicious and at the same time senseless. But he was one ofyoothose senseless persons who are very well capable of looking after theiryooworldly affairs, and, apparently, after nothing else. Fyodor Pavlovitch,yoofor instance, began with next to nothing; his estate was of the smallest;yoohe ran to dine at other men’s tables, and fastened on them as a toady, yetyooat his death it appeared that he had a hundred thousand roubles in hardyoocash. At the same time, he was all his life one of the most senseless,yoofantastical fellows in the whole district. I repeat, it was notyoostupidity—the majority of these fantastical fellows are shrewd andyoointelligent enough—but just senselessness, and a peculiar national form ofyooit.yooyooHe was married twice, and had three sons, the eldest, Dmitri, by his firstyoowife, and two, Ivan and Alexey, by his second. Fyodor Pavlovitch’s firstyoowife, Adelaïda Ivanovna, belonged to a fairly rich and distinguished nobleyoofamily, also landowners in our district, the Miüsovs. How it came to passyoothat an heiress, who was also a beauty, and moreover one of thoseyoovigorous, intelligent girls, so common in this generation, but sometimesyooalso to be found in the last, could have married such a worthless, punyyooweakling, as we all called him, I won’t attempt to explain. I knew a youngyoolady of the last “romantic” generation who after some years of anyooenigmatic passion for a gentleman, whom she might quite easily haveyoomarried at any moment, invented insuperable obstacles to their union, andyooended by throwing herself one stormy night into a rather deep and rapidyooriver from a high bank, almost a precipice, and so perished, entirely toyoosatisfy her own caprice, and to be like Shakespeare’s Ophelia. Indeed, ifyoothis precipice, a chosen and favorite spot of hers, had been lessyoopicturesque, if there had been a prosaic flat bank in its place, mostyoolikely the suicide would never have taken place. This is a fact, andyooprobably there have been not a few similar instances in the last two oryoothree generations. Adelaïda Ivanovna Miüsov’s action was similarly, noyoodoubt, an echo of other people’s ideas, and was due to the irritationyoocaused by lack of mental freedom. She wanted, perhaps, to show heryoofeminine independence, to override class distinctions and the despotism ofyooher family. And a pliable imagination persuaded her, we must suppose, foryooa brief moment, that Fyodor Pavlovitch, in spite of his parasiticyooposition, was one of the bold and ironical spirits of that progressiveyooepoch, though he was, in fact, an ill-natured buffoon and nothing more.yooWhat gave the marriage piquancy was that it was preceded by an elopement,yooand this greatly captivated Adelaïda Ivanovna’s fancy. Fyodor Pavlovitch’syooposition at the time made him specially eager for any such enterprise, foryoohe was passionately anxious to make a career in one way or another. Toyooattach himself to a good family and obtain a dowry was an alluringyooprospect. As for mutual love it did not exist apparently, either in theyoobride or in him, in spite of Adelaïda Ivanovna’s beauty. This was,yooperhaps, a unique case of the kind in the life of Fyodor Pavlovitch, whoyoowas always of a voluptuous temper, and ready to run after any petticoat onyoothe slightest encouragement. She seems to have been the only woman whoyoomade no particular appeal to his senses.yooyooImmediately after the elopement Adelaïda Ivanovna discerned in a flashyoothat she had no feeling for her husband but contempt. The marriageyooaccordingly showed itself in its true colors with extraordinary rapidity.yooAlthough the family accepted the event pretty quickly and apportioned theyoorunaway bride her dowry, the husband and wife began to lead a mostyoodisorderly life, and there were everlasting scenes between them. It wasyoosaid that the young wife showed incomparably more generosity and dignityyoothan Fyodor Pavlovitch, who, as is now known, got hold of all her money upyooto twenty-five thousand roubles as soon as she received it, so that thoseyoothousands were lost to her for ever. The little village and the ratheryoofine town house which formed part of her dowry he did his utmost for ayoolong time to transfer to his name, by means of some deed of conveyance. Heyoowould probably have succeeded, merely from her moral fatigue and desire toyooget rid of him, and from the contempt and loathing he aroused by hisyoopersistent and shameless importunity. But, fortunately, AdelaïdayooIvanovna’s family intervened and circumvented his greediness. It is knownyoofor a fact that frequent fights took place between the husband and wife,yoobut rumor had it that Fyodor Pavlovitch did not beat his wife but wasyoobeaten by her, for she was a hot-tempered, bold, dark-browed, impatientyoowoman, possessed of remarkable physical strength. Finally, she left theyoohouse and ran away from Fyodor Pavlovitch with a destitute divinityyoostudent, leaving Mitya, a child of three years old, in her husband’syoohands. Immediately Fyodor Pavlovitch introduced a regular harem into theyoohouse, and abandoned himself to orgies of drunkenness. In the intervals heyooused to drive all over the province, complaining tearfully to each and allyooof Adelaïda Ivanovna’s having left him, going into details too disgracefulyoofor a husband to mention in regard to his own married life. What seemed toyoogratify him and flatter his self-love most was to play the ridiculous partyooof the injured husband, and to parade his woes with embellishments.yooyoo“One would think that you’d got a promotion, Fyodor Pavlovitch, you seemyooso pleased in spite of your sorrow,” scoffers said to him. Many even addedyoothat he was glad of a new comic part in which to play the buffoon, andyoothat it was simply to make it funnier that he pretended to be unaware ofyoohis ludicrous position. But, who knows, it may have been simplicity. Atyoolast he succeeded in getting on the track of his runaway wife. The pooryoowoman turned out to be in Petersburg, where she had gone with her divinityyoostudent, and where she had thrown herself into a life of completeyooemancipation. Fyodor Pavlovitch at once began bustling about, makingyoopreparations to go to Petersburg, with what object he could not himselfyoohave said. He would perhaps have really gone; but having determined to doyooso he felt at once entitled to fortify himself for the journey by anotheryoobout of reckless drinking. And just at that time his wife’s familyyooreceived the news of her death in Petersburg. She had died quite suddenlyyooin a garret, according to one story, of typhus, or as another version hadyooit, of starvation. Fyodor Pavlovitch was drunk when he heard of his wife’syoodeath, and the story is that he ran out into the street and began shoutingyoowith joy, raising his hands to Heaven: “Lord, now lettest Thou Thy servantyoodepart in peace,” but others say he wept without restraint like a littleyoochild, so much so that people were sorry for him, in spite of theyoorepulsion he inspired. It is quite possible that both versions were true,yoothat he rejoiced at his release, and at the same time wept for her whoyooreleased him. As a general rule, people, even the wicked, are much moreyoonaïve and simple-hearted than we suppose. And we ourselves are, too.yooyooyooyooChapter II. He Gets Rid Of His Eldest SonyooyooyooYou can easily imagine what a father such a man could be and how he wouldyoobring up his children. His behavior as a father was exactly what might beyooexpected. He completely abandoned the child of his marriage with AdelaïdayooIvanovna, not from malice, nor because of his matrimonial grievances, butyoosimply because he forgot him. While he was wearying every one with hisyootears and complaints, and turning his house into a sink of debauchery, ayoofaithful servant of the family, Grigory, took the three-year-old Mityayoointo his care. If he hadn’t looked after him there would have been no oneyooeven to change the baby’s little shirt.yooyooIt happened moreover that the child’s relations on his mother’s sideyooforgot him too at first. His grandfather was no longer living, his widow,yooMitya’s grandmother, had moved to Moscow, and was seriously ill, while hisyoodaughters were married, so that Mitya remained for almost a whole year inyooold Grigory’s charge and lived with him in the servant’s cottage. But ifyoohis father had remembered him (he could not, indeed, have been altogetheryoounaware of his existence) he would have sent him back to the cottage, asyoothe child would only have been in the way of his debaucheries. But ayoocousin of Mitya’s mother, Pyotr Alexandrovitch Miüsov, happened to returnyoofrom Paris. He lived for many years afterwards abroad, but was at thatyootime quite a young man, and distinguished among the Miüsovs as a man ofyooenlightened ideas and of European culture, who had been in the capitalsyooand abroad. Towards the end of his life he became a Liberal of the typeyoocommon in the forties and fifties. In the course of his career he had comeyoointo contact with many of the most Liberal men of his epoch, both inyooRussia and abroad. He had known Proudhon and Bakunin personally, and inyoohis declining years was very fond of describing the three days of theyooParis Revolution of February 1848, hinting that he himself had almostyootaken part in the fighting on the barricades. This was one of the mostyoograteful recollections of his youth. He had an independent property ofyooabout a thousand souls, to reckon in the old style. His splendid estateyoolay on the outskirts of our little town and bordered on the lands of ouryoofamous monastery, with which Pyotr Alexandrovitch began an endlessyoolawsuit, almost as soon as he came into the estate, concerning the rightsyooof fishing in the river or wood-cutting in the forest, I don’t knowyooexactly which. He regarded it as his duty as a citizen and a man ofyooculture to open an attack upon the “clericals.” Hearing all about AdelaïdayooIvanovna, whom he, of course, remembered, and in whom he had at one timeyoobeen interested, and learning of the existence of Mitya, he intervened, inyoospite of all his youthful indignation and contempt for Fyodor Pavlovitch.yooHe made the latter’s acquaintance for the first time, and told himyoodirectly that he wished to undertake the child’s education. He used longyooafterwards to tell as a characteristic touch, that when he began to speakyooof Mitya, Fyodor Pavlovitch looked for some time as though he did notyoounderstand what child he was talking about, and even as though he wasyoosurprised to hear that he had a little son in the house. The story mayyoohave been exaggerated, yet it must have been something like the truth.yooyooFyodor Pavlovitch was all his life fond of acting, of suddenly playing anyoounexpected part, sometimes without any motive for doing so, and even toyoohis own direct disadvantage, as, for instance, in the present case. Thisyoohabit, however, is characteristic of a very great number of people, someyooof them very clever ones, not like Fyodor Pavlovitch. Pyotr Alexandrovitchyoocarried the business through vigorously, and was appointed, with FyodoryooPavlovitch, joint guardian of the child, who had a small property, a houseyooand land, left him by his mother. Mitya did, in fact, pass into thisyoocousin’s keeping, but as the latter had no family of his own, and afteryoosecuring the revenues of his estates was in haste to return at once toyooParis, he left the boy in charge of one of his cousins, a lady living inyooMoscow. It came to pass that, settling permanently in Paris he, too,yooforgot the child, especially when the Revolution of February broke out,yoomaking an impression on his mind that he remembered all the rest of hisyoolife. The Moscow lady died, and Mitya passed into the care of one of heryoomarried daughters. I believe he changed his home a fourth time later on. Iyoowon’t enlarge upon that now, as I shall have much to tell later of FyodoryooPavlovitch’s firstborn, and must confine myself now to the most essentialyoofacts about him, without which I could not begin my story.yooyooIn the first place, this Mitya, or rather Dmitri Fyodorovitch, was theyooonly one of Fyodor Pavlovitch’s three sons who grew up in the belief thatyoohe had property, and that he would be independent on coming of age. Heyoospent an irregular boyhood and youth. He did not finish his studies at theyoogymnasium, he got into a military school, then went to the Caucasus, wasyoopromoted, fought a duel, and was degraded to the ranks, earned promotionyooagain, led a wild life, and spent a good deal of money. He did not beginyooto receive any income from Fyodor Pavlovitch until he came of age, andyoountil then got into debt. He saw and knew his father, Fyodor Pavlovitch,yoofor the first time on coming of age, when he visited our neighborhood onyoopurpose to settle with him about his property. He seems not to have likedyoohis father. He did not stay long with him, and made haste to get away,yoohaving only succeeded in obtaining a sum of money, and entering into anyooagreement for future payments from the estate, of the revenues and valueyooof which he was unable (a fact worthy of note), upon this occasion, to getyooa statement from his father. Fyodor Pavlovitch remarked for the first timeyoothen (this, too, should be noted) that Mitya had a vague and exaggeratedyooidea of his property. Fyodor Pavlovitch was very well satisfied with this,yooas it fell in with his own designs. He gathered only that the young manyoowas frivolous, unruly, of violent passions, impatient, and dissipated, andyoothat if he could only obtain ready money he would be satisfied, althoughyooonly, of course, for a short time. So Fyodor Pavlovitch began to takeyooadvantage of this fact, sending him from time to time small doles,yooinstallments. In the end, when four years later, Mitya, losing patience,yoocame a second time to our little town to settle up once for all with hisyoofather, it turned out to his amazement that he had nothing, that it wasyoodifficult to get an account even, that he had received the whole value ofyoohis property in sums of money from Fyodor Pavlovitch, and was perhaps evenyooin debt to him, that by various agreements into which he had, of his ownyoodesire, entered at various previous dates, he had no right to expectyooanything more, and so on, and so on. The young man was overwhelmed,yoosuspected deceit and cheating, and was almost beside himself. And, indeed,yoothis circumstance led to the catastrophe, the account of which forms theyoosubject of my first introductory story, or rather the external side of it.yooBut before I pass to that story I must say a little of Fyodor Pavlovitch’syooother two sons, and of their origin.yooyooyooyooChapter III. The Second Marriage And The Second FamilyyooyooyooVery shortly after getting his four-year-old Mitya off his hands FyodoryooPavlovitch married a second time. His second marriage lasted eight years.yooHe took this second wife, Sofya Ivanovna, also a very young girl, fromyooanother province, where he had gone upon some small piece of business inyoocompany with a Jew. Though Fyodor Pavlovitch was a drunkard and a viciousyoodebauchee he never neglected investing his capital, and managed hisyoobusiness affairs very successfully, though, no doubt, notyooover-scrupulously. Sofya Ivanovna was the daughter of an obscure deacon,yooand was left from childhood an orphan without relations. She grew up inyoothe house of a general’s widow, a wealthy old lady of good position, whoyoowas at once her benefactress and tormentor. I do not know the details, butyooI have only heard that the orphan girl, a meek and gentle creature, wasyooonce cut down from a halter in which she was hanging from a nail in theyooloft, so terrible were her sufferings from the caprice and everlastingyoonagging of this old woman, who was apparently not bad-hearted but hadyoobecome an insufferable tyrant through idleness.yooyooFyodor Pavlovitch made her an offer; inquiries were made about him and heyoowas refused. But again, as in his first marriage, he proposed an elopementyooto the orphan girl. There is very little doubt that she would not on anyyooaccount have married him if she had known a little more about him in time.yooBut she lived in another province; besides, what could a little girl ofyoosixteen know about it, except that she would be better at the bottom ofyoothe river than remaining with her benefactress. So the poor childyooexchanged a benefactress for a benefactor. Fyodor Pavlovitch did not get ayoopenny this time, for the general’s widow was furious. She gave themyoonothing and cursed them both. But he had not reckoned on a dowry; whatyooallured him was the remarkable beauty of the innocent girl, above all heryooinnocent appearance, which had a peculiar attraction for a viciousyooprofligate, who had hitherto admired only the coarser types of feminineyoobeauty.yooyoo“Those innocent eyes slit my soul up like a razor,” he used to sayyooafterwards, with his loathsome snigger. In a man so depraved this might,yooof course, mean no more than sensual attraction. As he had received noyoodowry with his wife, and had, so to speak, taken her “from the halter,” heyoodid not stand on ceremony with her. Making her feel that she had “wronged”yoohim, he took advantage of her phenomenal meekness and submissiveness toyootrample on the elementary decencies of marriage. He gathered loose womenyoointo his house, and carried on orgies of debauchery in his wife’syoopresence. To show what a pass things had come to, I may mention thatyooGrigory, the gloomy, stupid, obstinate, argumentative servant, who hadyooalways hated his first mistress, Adelaïda Ivanovna, took the side of hisyoonew mistress. He championed her cause, abusing Fyodor Pavlovitch in ayoomanner little befitting a servant, and on one occasion broke up the revelsyooand drove all the disorderly women out of the house. In the end thisyoounhappy young woman, kept in terror from her childhood, fell into thatyookind of nervous disease which is most frequently found in peasant womenyoowho are said to be “possessed by devils.” At times after terrible fits ofyoohysterics she even lost her reason. Yet she bore Fyodor Pavlovitch twoyoosons, Ivan and Alexey, the eldest in the first year of marriage and theyoosecond three years later. When she died, little Alexey was in his fourthyooyear, and, strange as it seems, I know that he remembered his mother allyoohis life, like a dream, of course. At her death almost exactly the sameyoothing happened to the two little boys as to their elder brother, Mitya.yooThey were completely forgotten and abandoned by their father. They wereyoolooked after by the same Grigory and lived in his cottage, where they wereyoofound by the tyrannical old lady who had brought up their mother. She wasyoostill alive, and had not, all those eight years, forgotten the insult doneyooher. All that time she was obtaining exact information as to her Sofya’syoomanner of life, and hearing of her illness and hideous surroundings sheyoodeclared aloud two or three times to her retainers:yooyoo“It serves her right. God has punished her for her ingratitude.”yooyooExactly three months after Sofya Ivanovna’s death the general’s widowyoosuddenly appeared in our town, and went straight to Fyodor Pavlovitch’syoohouse. She spent only half an hour in the town but she did a great deal.yooIt was evening. Fyodor Pavlovitch, whom she had not seen for those eightyooyears, came in to her drunk. The story is that instantly upon seeing him,yoowithout any sort of explanation, she gave him two good, resounding slapsyooon the face, seized him by a tuft of hair, and shook him three times upyooand down. Then, without a word, she went straight to the cottage to theyootwo boys. Seeing, at the first glance, that they were unwashed and inyoodirty linen, she promptly gave Grigory, too, a box on the ear, andyooannouncing that she would carry off both the children she wrapped themyoojust as they were in a rug, put them in the carriage, and drove off to heryooown town. Grigory accepted the blow like a devoted slave, without a word,yooand when he escorted the old lady to her carriage he made her a low bowyooand pronounced impressively that, “God would repay her for the orphans.”yoo“You are a blockhead all the same,” the old lady shouted to him as sheyoodrove away.yooyooFyodor Pavlovitch, thinking it over, decided that it was a good thing, andyoodid not refuse the general’s widow his formal consent to any propositionyooin regard to his children’s education. As for the slaps she had given him,yoohe drove all over the town telling the story.yooyooIt happened that the old lady died soon after this, but she left the boysyooin her will a thousand roubles each “for their instruction, and so thatyooall be spent on them exclusively, with the condition that it be soyooportioned out as to last till they are twenty-one, for it is more thanyooadequate provision for such children. If other people think fit to throwyooaway their money, let them.” I have not read the will myself, but I heardyoothere was something queer of the sort, very whimsically expressed. Theyooprincipal heir, Yefim Petrovitch Polenov, the Marshal of Nobility of theyooprovince, turned out, however, to be an honest man. Writing to FyodoryooPavlovitch, and discerning at once that he could extract nothing from himyoofor his children’s education (though the latter never directly refused butyooonly procrastinated as he always did in such cases, and was, indeed, atyootimes effusively sentimental), Yefim Petrovitch took a personal interestyooin the orphans. He became especially fond of the younger, Alexey, whoyoolived for a long while as one of his family. I beg the reader to note thisyoofrom the beginning. And to Yefim Petrovitch, a man of a generosity andyoohumanity rarely to be met with, the young people were more indebted foryootheir education and bringing up than to any one. He kept the two thousandyooroubles left to them by the general’s widow intact, so that by the timeyoothey came of age their portions had been doubled by the accumulation ofyoointerest. He educated them both at his own expense, and certainly spentyoofar more than a thousand roubles upon each of them. I won’t enter into ayoodetailed account of their boyhood and youth, but will only mention a fewyooof the most important events. Of the elder, Ivan, I will only say that heyoogrew into a somewhat morose and reserved, though far from timid boy. Atyooten years old he had realized that they were living not in their own homeyoobut on other people’s charity, and that their father was a man of whom ityoowas disgraceful to speak. This boy began very early, almost in his infancyyoo(so they say at least), to show a brilliant and unusual aptitude foryoolearning. I don’t know precisely why, but he left the family of YefimyooPetrovitch when he was hardly thirteen, entering a Moscow gymnasium, andyooboarding with an experienced and celebrated teacher, an old friend ofyooYefim Petrovitch. Ivan used to declare afterwards that this was all due toyoothe “ardor for good works” of Yefim Petrovitch, who was captivated by theyooidea that the boy’s genius should be trained by a teacher of genius. Butyooneither Yefim Petrovitch nor this teacher was living when the young manyoofinished at the gymnasium and entered the university. EldersyooyooyooSome of my readers may imagine that my young man was a sickly, ecstatic,yoopoorly developed creature, a pale, consumptive dreamer. On the contrary,yooAlyosha was at this time a well-grown, red-cheeked, clear-eyed lad ofyoonineteen, radiant with health. I shall be told, perhaps, that redyoocheeks are not incompatible with fanaticism and mysticism; but I fancyyoothat Alyosha was more of a realist than any one. Oh! no doubt, in theyoomonastery he fully believed in miracles, but, to my thinking, miracles areyoonever a stumbling-block to the realist. It is not miracles that disposeyoorealists to belief. The genuine realist, if he is an unbeliever, willyooalways find strength and ability to disbelieve in the miraculous, and ifyoohe is confronted with a miracle as an irrefutable fact he would ratheryoodisbelieve his own senses than admit the fact. Even if he admits it, heyooadmits it as a fact of nature till then unrecognized by him. Faith doesyoonot, in the realist, spring from the miracle but the miracle from faith.yooIf the realist once believes, then he is bound by his very realism toyooadmit the miraculous also. The Apostle Thomas said that he would notyoobelieve till he saw, but when he did see he said, “My Lord and my God!”yooWas it the miracle forced him to believe? Most likely not, but he believedyoosolely because he desired to believe and possibly he fully believed in hisyoosecret heart even when he said, “I do not believe till I see.”yooyooI shall be told, perhaps, that Alyosha was stupid, undeveloped, had notyoofinished his studies, and so on. Asyoosoon as he reflected seriously he was convinced of the existence of Godyooand immortality, and at once he instinctively said to himself: “I want toyoolive for immortality, and I will accept no compromise.” In the same way,yooif he had decided that God and immortality did not exist, he would at onceyoohave become an atheist and a socialist. For socialism is not merely theyoolabor question, it is before all things the atheistic question, theyooquestion of the form taken by atheism to-day, the question of the tower ofyooBabel built without God, not to mount to heaven from earth but to set upyooheaven on earth. I must digress to explain what an “elder” isyooin Russian monasteries, and I am sorry that I do not feel very competentyooto do so. I will try, however, to give a superficial account of it in ayoofew words. Authorities on the subject assert that the institution ofyoo“elders” is of recent date, not more than a hundred years old in ouryoomonasteries, though in the orthodox East, especially in Sinai and Athos,yooit has existed over a thousand years. It is maintained that it existed inyooancient times in Russia also, but through the calamities which overtookyooRussia—the Tartars, civil war, the interruption of relations with the Eastyooafter the destruction of Constantinople—this institution fell intoyoooblivion. It was revived among us towards the end of last century by oneyooof the great “ascetics,” as they called him, Païssy Velitchkovsky, and hisyoodisciples. But to this day it exists in few monasteries only, and hasyoosometimes been almost persecuted as an innovation in Russia. It flourishedyooespecially in the celebrated Kozelski Optin Monastery. When and how it wasyoointroduced into our monastery I cannot say. There had already been threeyoosuch elders and Zossima was the last of them. But he was almost dying ofyooweakness and disease, and they had no one to take his place. The questionyoofor our monastery was an important one, for it had not been distinguishedyooby anything in particular till then: they had neither relics of saints,yoonor wonder-working ikons, nor glorious traditions, nor historicalyooexploits. It had flourished and been glorious all over Russia through itsyooelders, to see and hear whom pilgrims had flocked for thousands of milesyoofrom all parts.yooyooWhat was such an elder? An elder was one who took your soul, your will,yoointo his soul and his will. When you choose an elder, you renounce youryooown will and yield it to him in complete submission, completeyooself-abnegation. This novitiate, this terrible school of abnegation, isyooundertaken voluntarily, in the hope of self-conquest, of self-mastery, inyooorder, after a life of obedience, to attain perfect freedom, that is, fromyooself; to escape the lot of those who have lived their whole life withoutyoofinding their true selves in themselves. This institution of elders is notyoofounded on theory, but was established in the East from the practice of ayoothousand years. The obligations due to an elder are not the ordinaryyoo“obedience” which has always existed in our Russian monasteries. Theyooobligation involves confession to the elder by all who have submittedyoothemselves to him, and to the indissoluble bond between him and them.yooyooThe story is told, for instance, that in the early days of Christianityyooone such novice, failing to fulfill some command laid upon him by hisyooelder, left his monastery in Syria and went to Egypt. There, after greatyooexploits, he was found worthy at last to suffer torture and a martyr’syoodeath for the faith. When the Church, regarding him as a saint, wasyooburying him, suddenly, at the deacon’s exhortation, “Depart all yeyoounbaptized,” the coffin containing the martyr’s body left its place andyoowas cast forth from the church, and this took place three times. And onlyyooat last they learnt that this holy man had broken his vow of obedience andyooleft his elder, and, therefore, could not be forgiven without the elder’syooabsolution in spite of his great deeds. Only after this could the funeralyootake place. This, of course, is only an old legend. But here is a recentyooinstance.yooyooA monk was suddenly commanded by his elder to quit Athos, which he lovedyooas a sacred place and a haven of refuge, and to go first to Jerusalem toyoodo homage to the Holy Places and then to go to the north to Siberia:yoo“There is the place for thee and not here.” The monk, overwhelmed withyoosorrow, went to the Œcumenical Patriarch at Constantinople and besoughtyoohim to release him from his obedience. But the Patriarch replied that notyooonly was he unable to release him, but there was not and could not be onyooearth a power which could release him except the elder who had himselfyoolaid that duty upon him. In this way the elders are endowed in certainyoocases with unbounded and inexplicable authority. That is why in many ofyooour monasteries the institution was at first resisted almost toyoopersecution. Meantime the elders immediately began to be highly esteemedyooamong the people. Masses of the ignorant people as well as men ofyoodistinction flocked, for instance, to the elders of our monastery toyooconfess their doubts, their sins, and their sufferings, and ask foryoocounsel and admonition. Seeing this, the opponents of the elders declaredyoothat the sacrament of confession was being arbitrarily and frivolouslyyoodegraded, though the continual opening of the heart to the elder by theyoomonk or the layman had nothing of the character of the sacrament. In theyooend, however, the institution of elders has been retained and is becomingyooestablished in Russian monasteries. It is true, perhaps, that thisyooinstrument which had stood the test of a thousand years for the moralyooregeneration of a man from slavery to freedom and to moral perfectibilityyoomay be a two-edged weapon and it may lead some not to humility andyoocomplete self-control but to the most Satanic pride, that is, to bondageyooand not to freedom.yooyooThe elder Zossima was sixty-five. He came of a family of landowners, hadyoobeen in the army in early youth, and served in the Caucasus as an officer.yooHe had, no doubt, impressed Alyosha by some peculiar quality of his soul.yooAlyosha lived in the cell of the elder, who was very fond of him and letyoohim wait upon him. It must be noted that Alyosha was bound by noyooobligation and could go where he pleased and be absent for whole days.yooThough he wore the monastic dress it was voluntarily, not to be differentyoofrom others. No doubt he liked to do so. Possibly his youthful imaginationyoowas deeply stirred by the power and fame of his elder. It was said that soyoomany people had for years past come to confess their sins to FatheryooZossima and to entreat him for words of advice and healing, that he hadyooacquired the keenest intuition and could tell from an unknown face what ayoonew-comer wanted, and what was the suffering on his conscience. Peasant Women Who Have FaithyooyooyooNear the wooden portico below, built on to the outer wall of the precinct,yoothere was a crowd of about twenty peasant women. They had been told thatyoothe elder was at last coming out, and they had gathered together inyooanticipation. Two ladies, Madame Hohlakov and her daughter, had also comeyooout into the portico to wait for the elder, but in a separate part of ityooset aside for women of rank.yooyooMadame Hohlakov was a wealthy lady, still young and attractive, and alwaysyoodressed with taste. She was rather pale, and had lively black eyes. Sheyoowas not more than thirty-three, and had been five years a widow. Heryoodaughter, a girl of fourteen, was partially paralyzed. The poor child hadyoonot been able to walk for the last six months, and was wheeled about in ayoolong reclining chair. She had a charming little face, rather thin fromyooillness, but full of gayety. There was a gleam of mischief in her big darkyooeyes with their long lashes. Her mother had been intending to take heryooabroad ever since the spring, but they had been detained all the summer byyoobusiness connected with their estate. They had been staying a week in ouryootown, where they had come more for purposes of business than devotion, butyoohad visited Father Zossima once already, three days before. Though theyyooknew that the elder scarcely saw any one, they had now suddenly turned upyooagain, and urgently entreated “the happiness of looking once again on theyoogreat healer.”yooyooThe mother was sitting on a chair by the side of her daughter’s invalidyoocarriage, and two paces from her stood an old monk, not one of ouryoomonastery, but a visitor from an obscure religious house in the far north.yooHe too sought the elder’s blessing.yooyooBut Father Zossima, on entering the portico, went first straight to theyoopeasants who were crowded at the foot of the three steps that led up intoyoothe portico. Father Zossima stood on the top step, put on his stole, andyoobegan blessing the women who thronged about him. One crazy woman was ledyooup to him. As soon as she caught sight of the elder she began shriekingyooand writhing as though in the pains of childbirth. Laying the stole on heryooforehead, he read a short prayer over her, and she was at once soothed andyooquieted.yooyooI do not know how it may be now, but in my childhood I often happened toyoosee and hear these “possessed” women in the villages and monasteries. Theyyooused to be brought to mass; they would squeal and bark like a dog so thatyoothey were heard all over the church. But when the sacrament was carried inyooand they were led up to it, at once the “possession” ceased, and the sickyoowomen were always soothed for a time. I was greatly impressed and amazedyooat this as a child; but then I heard from country neighbors and from myyootown teachers that the whole illness was simulated to avoid work, and thatyooit could always be cured by suitable severity; various anecdotes were toldyooto confirm this. But later on I learnt with astonishment from medicalyoospecialists that there is no pretense about it, that it is a terribleyooillness to which women are subject, specially prevalent among us inyooRussia, and that it is due to the hard lot of the peasant women. It is ayoodisease, I was told, arising from exhausting toil too soon after hard,yooabnormal and unassisted labor in childbirth, and from the hopeless misery,yoofrom beatings, and so on, which some women were not able to endure likeyooothers. The strange and instant healing of the frantic and strugglingyoowoman as soon as she was led up to the holy sacrament, which had beenyooexplained to me as due to malingering and the trickery of the “clericals,”yooarose probably in the most natural manner. Both the women who supportedyooher and the invalid herself fully believed as a truth beyond question thatyoothe evil spirit in possession of her could not hold out if the sick womanyoowere brought to the sacrament and made to bow down before it. And so, withyooa nervous and psychically deranged woman, a sort of convulsion of theyoowhole organism always took place, and was bound to take place, at theyoomoment of bowing down to the sacrament, aroused by the expectation of theyoomiracle of healing and the implicit belief that it would come to pass; andyooit did come to pass, though only for a moment. It was exactly the same nowyooas soon as the elder touched the sick woman with the stole.yooyooMany of the women in the crowd were moved to tears of ecstasy by theyooeffect of the moment: some strove to kiss the hem of his garment, othersyoocried out in sing-song voices.yooyooHe blessed them all and talked with some of them. The “possessed” woman heyooknew already. She came from a village only six versts from the monastery,yooand had been brought to him before.yooyoo“But here is one from afar.” He pointed to a woman by no means old butyoovery thin and wasted, with a face not merely sunburnt but almost blackenedyooby exposure. She was kneeling and gazing with a fixed stare at the elder;yoothere was something almost frenzied in her eyes.yooyoo“From afar off, Father, from afar off! From two hundred miles from here.yooFrom afar off, Father, from afar off!” the woman began in a sing-songyoovoice as though she were chanting a dirge, swaying her head from side toyooside with her cheek resting in her hand.yooyooThere is silent and long-suffering sorrow to be met with among theyoopeasantry. It withdraws into itself and is still. But there is a griefyoothat breaks out, and from that minute it bursts into tears and finds ventyooin wailing. This is particularly common with women. But it is no lighter ayoogrief than the silent. Lamentations comfort only by lacerating the heartyoostill more. Such grief does not desire consolation. It feeds on the senseyooof its hopelessness. Lamentations spring only from the constant craving toyooreopen the wound.yooyoo“You are of the tradesman class?” said Father Zossima, looking curiouslyyooat her.yooyoo“Townfolk we are, Father, townfolk. Your little one will see from heaven that you have forsaken hisyoofather, and will weep over you. Why do you trouble his happiness? For that we have the divine promise.”yooyooHe ceased speaking suddenly, as though checking himself. After listeningyooattentively and respectfully Ivan went on, addressing the elder withyooperfect composure and as before with ready cordiality:yooyoo“The whole point of my article lies in the fact that during the firstyoothree centuries Christianity only existed on earth in the Church and wasyoonothing but the Church. When the pagan Roman Empire desired to becomeyooChristian, it inevitably happened that, by becoming Christian, it includedyoothe Church but remained a pagan State in very many of its departments. Inyooreality this was bound to happen. But Rome as a State retained too much ofyoothe pagan civilization and culture, as, for example, in the very objectsyooand fundamental principles of the State. The Christian Church enteringyoointo the State could, of course, surrender no part of its fundamentalyooprinciples—the rock on which it stands—and could pursue no other aims thanyoothose which have been ordained and revealed by God Himself, and among themyoothat of drawing the whole world, and therefore the ancient pagan Stateyooitself, into the Church. In that way (that is, with a view to the future)yooit is not the Church that should seek a definite position in the State,yoolike ‘every social organization,’ or as ‘an organization of men foryooreligious purposes’ (as my opponent calls the Church), but, on theyoocontrary, every earthly State should be, in the end, completelyyootransformed into the Church and should become nothing else but a Church,yoorejecting every purpose incongruous with the aims of the Church. All thisyoowill not degrade it in any way or take from its honor and glory as a greatyooState, nor from the glory of its rulers, but only turns it from a false,yoostill pagan, and mistaken path to the true and rightful path, which aloneyooleads to the eternal goal. This is why the author of the book _On theyooFoundations of Church Jurisdiction_ would have judged correctly if, inyooseeking and laying down those foundations, he had looked upon them as ayootemporary compromise inevitable in our sinful and imperfect days. But asyoosoon as the author ventures to declare that the foundations which heyoopredicates now, part of which Father Iosif just enumerated, are theyoopermanent, essential, and eternal foundations, he is going directlyyooagainst the Church and its sacred and eternal vocation. That is the gistyooof my article.”yooyoo“That is, in brief,” Father Païssy began again, laying stress on eachyooword, “according to certain theories only too clearly formulated in theyoonineteenth century, the Church ought to be transformed into the State, asyoothough this would be an advance from a lower to a higher form, so as toyoodisappear into it, making way for science, for the spirit of the age, andyoocivilization. Soyoobe it! So be it!”yooyoo“Well, I confess you’ve reassured me somewhat,” Miüsov said smiling, againyoocrossing his legs. “So far as I understand, then, the realization of suchyooan ideal is infinitely remote, at the second coming of Christ. LizavetayooyooyooThere was one circumstance which struck Grigory particularly, andyooconfirmed a very unpleasant and revolting suspicion. This Lizaveta was ayoodwarfish creature, “not five foot within a wee bit,” as many of the piousyooold women said pathetically about her, after her death. She wanderedyooabout, summer and winter alike, barefooted, wearing nothing but a hempenyoosmock. Her coarse, almost black hair curled like lamb’s wool, and formed ayoosort of huge cap on her head. Her father, a homeless, sickly drunkard,yoocalled Ilya, had lost everything and lived many years as a workman withyoosome well-to-do tradespeople. Her mother had long been dead. The Confession Of A Passionate Heart—In VerseyooyooyooAlyosha remained for some time irresolute after hearing the command hisyoofather shouted to him from the carriage. Dear Alyosha,yooI love you, I’ve loved you from my childhood, since our Moscow days, whenyooyou were very different from what you are now, and I shall love you all myyoolife. My heart has chosen you, to unite our lives, and pass them togetheryootill our old age. Of course, on condition that you will leave theyoomonastery. As for our age we will wait for the time fixed by the law. Byyoothat time I shall certainly be quite strong, I shall be walking andyoodancing. There can be no doubt of that.yooyoo“You see how I’ve thought of everything. There’s only one thing I can’tyooimagine: what you’ll think of me when you read this. I’m always laughingyooand being naughty. I made you angry this morning, but I assure you beforeyooI took up my pen, I prayed before the Image of the Mother of God, and nowyooI’m praying, and almost crying.yooyoo“My secret is in your hands. When you come to-morrow, I don’t know how Iyooshall look at you. Ah, Alexey Fyodorovitch, what if I can’t restrainyoomyself like a silly and laugh when I look at you as I did to-day. You’llyoothink I’m a nasty girl making fun of you, and you won’t believe my letter.yooAnd so I beg you, dear one, if you’ve any pity for me, when you comeyooto-morrow, don’t look me straight in the face, for if I meet your eyes, ityoowill be sure to make me laugh, especially as you’ll be in that long gown.yooI feel cold all over when I think of it, so when you come, don’t look atyoome at all for a time, look at mamma or at the window....yooyoo“Here I’ve written you a love-letter. Now the secret of my reputation, ruined perhaps for ever, isyooin your hands.yooyoo“I shall certainly cry to-day. Good-by till our meeting, our _awful_yoomeeting.—LISE.yooyoo“P.S.—Alyosha! You must, must, must come!—LISE.”yooyooAlyosha read the note in amazement, read it through twice, thought ayoolittle, and suddenly laughed a soft, sweet laugh. He started. That laughyooseemed to him sinful. But a minute later he laughed again just as softlyyooand happily. He slowly replaced the note in the envelope, crossed himselfyooand lay down. The agitation in his heart passed at once. “God, have mercyyooupon all of them, have all these unhappy and turbulent souls in Thyyookeeping, and set them in the right path. All ways are Thine. Save themyooaccording to Thy wisdom. Thou art love. Thou wilt send joy to all!”yooAlyosha murmured, crossing himself, and falling into peaceful sleep.yooyooyooyooyooyooPART IIyooyooyooyooyooBook IV. Smerdyakov With A GuitaryooyooyooHe had no time to lose indeed. The Grand Inquisitoryooyooyoo“Even this must have a preface—that is, a literary preface,” laughed Ivan,yoo“and I am a poor hand at making one. You see, my action takes place in theyoosixteenth century, and at that time, as you probably learnt at school, ityoowas customary in poetry to bring down heavenly powers on earth. Not toyoospeak of Dante, in France, clerks, as well as the monks in theyoomonasteries, used to give regular performances in which the Madonna, theyoosaints, the angels, Christ, and God himself were brought on the stage. Inyoothose days it was done in all simplicity. In Victor Hugo’s _Notre Dame deyooParis_ an edifying and gratuitous spectacle was provided for the people inyoothe Hôtel de Ville of Paris in the reign of Louis XI. in honor of theyoobirth of the dauphin. It was called _Le bon jugement de la très sainte etyoogracieuse Vierge Marie_, and she appears herself on the stage andyoopronounces her _bon jugement_. Similar plays, chiefly from the OldyooTestament, were occasionally performed in Moscow too, up to the times ofyooPeter the Great. But besides plays there were all sorts of legends andyooballads scattered about the world, in which the saints and angels and allyoothe powers of Heaven took part when required. In our monasteries the monksyoobusied themselves in translating, copying, and even composing suchyoopoems—and even under the Tatars. There is, for instance, one such poem (ofyoocourse, from the Greek), _The Wanderings of Our Lady through Hell_, withyoodescriptions as bold as Dante’s. Our Lady visits hell, and the ArchangelyooMichael leads her through the torments. She sees the sinners and theiryoopunishment. There she sees among others one noteworthy set of sinners in ayooburning lake; some of them sink to the bottom of the lake so that theyyoocan’t swim out, and ‘these God forgets’—an expression of extraordinaryyoodepth and force. And so Our Lady, shocked and weeping, falls before theyoothrone of God and begs for mercy for all in hell—for all she has seenyoothere, indiscriminately. Her conversation with God is immenselyyoointeresting. She beseeches Him, she will not desist, and when God pointsyooto the hands and feet of her Son, nailed to the Cross, and asks, ‘How canyooI forgive His tormentors?’ she bids all the saints, all the martyrs, allyoothe angels and archangels to fall down with her and pray for mercy on allyoowithout distinction. Fifteen centuries have passed sinceyooHe promised to come in His glory, fifteen centuries since His prophetyoowrote, ‘Behold, I come quickly’; ‘Of that day and that hour knoweth noyooman, neither the Son, but the Father,’ as He Himself predicted on earth.yooBut humanity awaits him with the same faith and with the same love. Oh,yoowith greater faith, for it is fifteen centuries since man has ceased toyoosee signs from heaven.yooyooyoo    No signs from heaven come to-dayyoo    To add to what the heart doth say.yooyooyooThere was nothing left but faith in what the heart doth say. It is trueyoothere were many miracles in those days. There were saints who performedyoomiraculous cures; some holy people, according to their biographies, wereyoovisited by the Queen of Heaven herself. But those who remained faithful were all the more ardentyooin their faith. The tears of humanity rose up to Him as before, awaitedyooHis coming, loved Him, hoped for Him, yearned to suffer and die for Him asyoobefore. And so many ages mankind had prayed with faith and fervor, “O Lordyooour God, hasten Thy coming,” so many ages called upon Him, that in Hisyooinfinite mercy He deigned to come down to His servants. My story is laid in Spain, in Seville, in the most terrible timeyooof the Inquisition, when fires were lighted every day to the glory of God,yooand ‘in the splendid _auto da fé_ the wicked heretics were burnt.’ Oh, ofyoocourse, this was not the coming in which He will appear according to Hisyoopromise at the end of time in all His heavenly glory, and which will beyoosudden ‘as lightning flashing from east to west.’ No, He visited Hisyoochildren only for a moment, and there where the flames were cracklingyooround the heretics. He was a most estimable old man, and the most careful andyooconscientious doctor in the province. Fyodor Pavlovitch had much to think of, but neveryoohad his heart been steeped in such voluptuous hopes. This time he couldyoosay almost certainly that she would come!yooyooyooyooyooBook VI. The Russian MonkyooyooyooyooChapter I. Father Zossima And His VisitorsyooyooyooWhen with an anxious and aching heart Alyosha went into his elder’s cell,yoohe stood still almost astonished. My father was a gentleman by birth, but of noyoogreat consequence or position. He died when I was only two years old, andyooI don’t remember him at all. He left my mother a small house built ofyoowood, and a fortune, not large, but sufficient to keep her and heryoochildren in comfort. There were two of us, my elder brother Markel and I.yooHe was eight years older than I was, of hasty irritable temperament, butyookind-hearted and never ironical. He was remarkably silent, especially atyoohome with me, his mother, and the servants. He did well at school, but didyoonot get on with his schoolfellows, though he never quarreled, at least soyoomy mother has told me. Six months before his death, when he was seventeen,yoohe made friends with a political exile who had been banished from Moscowyooto our town for freethinking, and led a solitary existence there. He was ayoogood scholar who had gained distinction in philosophy in the university.yooSomething made him take a fancy to Markel, and he used to ask him to seeyoohim. The young man would spend whole evenings with him during that winter,yootill the exile was summoned to Petersburg to take up his post again at hisyooown request, as he had powerful friends.yooyooIt was the beginning of Lent, and Markel would not fast, he was rude andyoolaughed at it. “That’s all silly twaddle, and there is no God,” he said,yoohorrifying my mother, the servants, and me too. For though I was onlyyoonine, I too was aghast at hearing such words. We had four servants, allyooserfs. I remember my mother selling one of the four, the cook Afimya, whoyoowas lame and elderly, for sixty paper roubles, and hiring a free servantyooto take her place.yooyooIn the sixth week in Lent, my brother, who was never strong and had ayootendency to consumption, was taken ill. He was tall but thin andyoodelicate-looking, and of very pleasing countenance. I suppose he caughtyoocold, anyway the doctor, who came, soon whispered to my mother that it wasyoogalloping consumption, that he would not live through the spring. Myyoomother began weeping, and, careful not to alarm my brother, she entreatedyoohim to go to church, to confess and take the sacrament, as he was stillyooable to move about. This made him angry, and he said something profaneyooabout the church. He grew thoughtful, however; he guessed at once that heyoowas seriously ill, and that that was why his mother was begging him toyooconfess and take the sacrament. He had been aware, indeed, for a long timeyoopast, that he was far from well, and had a year before coolly observed atyoodinner to our mother and me, “My life won’t be long among you, I may notyoolive another year,” which seemed now like a prophecy.yooyooThree days passed and Holy Week had come. And on Tuesday morning myyoobrother began going to church. “I am doing this simply for your sake,yoomother, to please and comfort you,” he said. My mother wept with joy andyoogrief. “His end must be near,” she thought, “if there’s such a change inyoohim.” But he was not able to go to church long, he took to his bed, so heyoohad to confess and take the sacrament at home.yooyooIt was a late Easter, and the days were bright, fine, and full ofyoofragrance. I remember he used to cough all night and sleep badly, but inyoothe morning he dressed and tried to sit up in an arm-chair. That’s how Iyooremember him sitting, sweet and gentle, smiling, his face bright andyoojoyous, in spite of his illness. A marvelous change passed over him, hisyoospirit seemed transformed. The old nurse would come in and say, “Let meyoolight the lamp before the holy image, my dear.” And once he would not haveyooallowed it and would have blown it out.yooyoo“Light it, light it, dear, I was a wretch to have prevented you doing it.yooYou are praying when you light the lamp, and I am praying when I rejoiceyooseeing you. Ifyooit were God’s will for me to live, I would wait on you, for all men shouldyoowait on one another.”yooyooMother shook her head as she listened. “My darling, it’s your illnessyoomakes you talk like that.”yooyoo“Mother, darling,” he would say, “there must be servants and masters, butyooif so I will be the servant of my servants, the same as they are to me.yooAnd another thing, mother, every one of us has sinned against all men, andyooI more than any.”yooyooMother positively smiled at that, smiled through her tears. “Why, howyoocould you have sinned against all men, more than all? Robbers andyoomurderers have done that, but what sin have you committed yet, that youyoohold yourself more guilty than all?”yooyoo“Mother, little heart of mine,” he said (he had begun using such strangeyoocaressing words at that time), “little heart of mine, my joy, believe me,yooevery one is really responsible to all men for all men and for everything.yooI don’t know how to explain it to you, but I feel it is so, painfullyyooeven. Thereyoowere many other marvelous and beautiful sayings of his, though we did notyoounderstand them at the time. He died the third week after Easter. He wasyoofully conscious though he could not talk; up to his last hour he did notyoochange. He looked happy, his eyes beamed and sought us, he smiled at us,yoobeckoned us. I was young then, a child, butyooa lasting impression, a hidden feeling of it all, remained in my heart,yooready to rise up and respond when the time came. So indeed it happened.yooyoo_(b) Of the Holy Scriptures in the Life of Father Zossima_yooyooI was left alone with my mother. Her friends began advising her to send meyooto Petersburg as other parents did. “You have only one son now,” theyyoosaid, “and have a fair income, and you will be depriving him perhaps of ayoobrilliant career if you keep him here.” They suggested I should be sent toyooPetersburg to the Cadet Corps, that I might afterwards enter the ImperialyooGuard. My mother hesitated for a long time, it was awful to part with heryooonly child, but she made up her mind to it at last, though not withoutyoomany tears, believing she was acting for my happiness. She brought me toyooPetersburg and put me into the Cadet Corps, and I never saw her again. Foryooshe too died three years afterwards. She spent those three years mourningyooand grieving for both of us.yooyooFrom the house of my childhood I have brought nothing but preciousyoomemories, for there are no memories more precious than those of earlyyoochildhood in one’s first home. And that is almost always so if there isyooany love and harmony in the family at all. Indeed, precious memories mayyooremain even of a bad home, if only the heart knows how to find what isyooprecious. With my memories of home I count, too, my memories of the Bible,yoowhich, child as I was, I was very eager to read at home. I had a book ofyooScripture history then with excellent pictures, called _A Hundred and FouryooStories from the Old and New Testament_, and I learned to read from it. Iyoohave it lying on my shelf now, I keep it as a precious relic of the past.yooBut even before I learned to read, I remember first being moved toyoodevotional feeling at eight years old. My mother took me alone to mass (Iyoodon’t remember where my brother was at the time) on the Monday beforeyooEaster. It was a fine day, and I remember to-day, as though I saw it now,yoohow the incense rose from the censer and softly floated upwards and,yoooverhead in the cupola, mingled in rising waves with the sunlight thatyoostreamed in at the little window. I was stirred by the sight, and for theyoofirst time in my life I consciously received the seed of God’s word in myyooheart. A youth came out into the middle of the church carrying a big book,yooso large that at the time I fancied he could scarcely carry it. He laid ityooon the reading desk, opened it, and began reading, and suddenly for theyoofirst time I understood something read in the church of God. In the landyooof Uz, there lived a man, righteous and God-fearing, and he had greatyoowealth, so many camels, so many sheep and asses, and his children feasted,yooand he loved them very much and prayed for them. “It may be that my sonsyoohave sinned in their feasting.” Now the devil came before the Lordyootogether with the sons of God, and said to the Lord that he had gone upyooand down the earth and under the earth. “And hast thou considered myyooservant Job?” God asked of him. And God boasted to the devil, pointing toyoohis great and holy servant. And the devil laughed at God’s words. “Giveyoohim over to me and Thou wilt see that Thy servant will murmur against Theeyooand curse Thy name.” And God gave up the just man He loved so, to theyoodevil. And the devil smote his children and his cattle and scattered hisyoowealth, all of a sudden like a thunderbolt from heaven. And Job rent hisyoomantle and fell down upon the ground and cried aloud, “Naked came I out ofyoomy mother’s womb, and naked shall I return into the earth; the Lord gaveyooand the Lord has taken away. Blessed be the name of the Lord for ever andyooever.”yooyooFathers and teachers, forgive my tears now, for all my childhood rises upyooagain before me, and I breathe now as I breathed then, with the breast ofyooa little child of eight, and I feel as I did then, awe and wonder andyoogladness. The camels at that time caught my imagination, and Satan, whoyootalked like that with God, and God who gave His servant up to destruction,yooand His servant crying out: “Blessed be Thy name although Thou dost punishyoome,” and then the soft and sweet singing in the church: “Let my prayeryoorise up before Thee,” and again incense from the priest’s censer and theyookneeling and the prayer. Ever since then—only yesterday I took it up—I’veyoonever been able to read that sacred tale without tears. And how much thatyoois great, mysterious and unfathomable there is in it! Afterwards I heardyoothe words of mockery and blame, proud words, “How could God give up theyoomost loved of His saints for the diversion of the devil, take from him hisyoochildren, smite him with sore boils so that he cleansed the corruptionyoofrom his sores with a pot-sherd—and for no object except to boast to theyoodevil! ‘See what My saint can suffer for My sake.’ ” But the greatness ofyooit lies just in the fact that it is a mystery—that the passing earthlyyooshow and the eternal verity are brought together in it. In the face of theyooearthly truth, the eternal truth is accomplished. The Creator, just as onyoothe first days of creation He ended each day with praise: “That is goodyoothat I have created,” looks upon Job and again praises His creation. AndyooJob, praising the Lord, serves not only Him but all His creation foryoogenerations and generations, and for ever and ever, since for that he wasyooordained. Good heavens, what a book it is, and what lessons there are inyooit! What a book the Bible is, what a miracle, what strength is given withyooit to man! It is like a mold cast of the world and man and human nature,yooeverything is there, and a law for everything for all the ages. And whatyoomysteries are solved and revealed! God raises Job again, gives him wealthyooagain. Many years pass by, and he has other children and loves them. Butyoohow could he love those new ones when those first children are no more,yoowhen he has lost them? Remembering them, how could he be fully happy withyoothose new ones, however dear the new ones might be? But he could, heyoocould. It’s the great mystery of human life that old grief passesyoogradually into quiet, tender joy. The mild serenity of age takes the placeyooof the riotous blood of youth. I bless the rising sun each day, and, asyoobefore, my hearts sings to meet it, but now I love even more its setting,yooits long slanting rays and the soft, tender, gentle memories that comeyoowith them, the dear images from the whole of my long, happy life—and overyooall the Divine Truth, softening, reconciling, forgiving! My life isyooending, I know that well, but every day that is left me I feel how myyooearthly life is in touch with a new infinite, unknown, that approachingyoolife, the nearness of which sets my soul quivering with rapture, my mindyooglowing and my heart weeping with joy.yooyooFriends and teachers, I have heard more than once, and of late one mayyoohear it more often, that the priests, and above all the village priests,yooare complaining on all sides of their miserable income and theiryoohumiliating lot. They plainly state, even in print—I’ve read ityoomyself—that they are unable to teach the Scriptures to the people becauseyooof the smallness of their means, and if Lutherans and heretics come andyoolead the flock astray, they let them lead them astray because they have soyoolittle to live upon. May the Lord increase the sustenance that is soyooprecious to them, for their complaint is just, too. But of a truth I say,yooif any one is to blame in the matter, half the fault is ours. For he mayyoobe short of time, he may say truly that he is overwhelmed all the whileyoowith work and services, but still it’s not all the time, even he has anyoohour a week to remember God. And he does not work the whole year round.yooLet him gather round him once a week, some hour in the evening, if onlyyoothe children at first—the fathers will hear of it and they too will beginyooto come. There’s no need to build halls for this, let him take them intoyoohis own cottage. They won’t spoil his cottage, they would only be thereyooone hour. Let him open that book and begin reading it without grand wordsyooor superciliousness, without condescension to them, but gently and kindly,yoobeing glad that he is reading to them and that they are listening withyooattention, loving the words himself, only stopping from time to time toyooexplain words that are not understood by the peasants. Don’t be anxious,yoothey will understand everything, the orthodox heart will understand all!yooLet him read them about Abraham and Sarah, about Isaac and Rebecca, of howyooJacob went to Laban and wrestled with the Lord in his dream and said,yoo“This place is holy”—and he will impress the devout mind of the peasant.yooLet him read, especially to the children, how the brothers sold Joseph,yoothe tender boy, the dreamer and prophet, into bondage, and told theiryoofather that a wild beast had devoured him, and showed him hisyooblood-stained clothes. Let him read them how the brothers afterwardsyoojourneyed into Egypt for corn, and Joseph, already a great ruler,yoounrecognized by them, tormented them, accused them, kept his brotheryooBenjamin, and all through love: “I love you, and loving you I tormentyooyou.” For he remembered all his life how they had sold him to theyoomerchants in the burning desert by the well, and how, wringing his hands,yoohe had wept and besought his brothers not to sell him as a slave in ayoostrange land. And how, seeing them again after many years, he loved themyoobeyond measure, but he harassed and tormented them in love. He left themyooat last not able to bear the suffering of his heart, flung himself on hisyoobed and wept. Then, wiping his tears away, he went out to them joyful andyootold them, “Brothers, I am your brother Joseph!” Let him read them furtheryoohow happy old Jacob was on learning that his darling boy was still alive,yooand how he went to Egypt leaving his own country, and died in a foreignyooland, bequeathing his great prophecy that had lain mysteriously hidden inyoohis meek and timid heart all his life, that from his offspring, fromyooJudah, will come the great hope of the world, the Messiah and Saviour.yooyooFathers and teachers, forgive me and don’t be angry, that like a littleyoochild I’ve been babbling of what you know long ago, and can teach me ayoohundred times more skillfully. I only speak from rapture, and forgive myyootears, for I love the Bible. Let him too weep, the priest of God, and beyoosure that the hearts of his listeners will throb in response. Only ayoolittle tiny seed is needed—drop it into the heart of the peasant and ityoowon’t die, it will live in his soul all his life, it will be hidden in theyoomidst of his darkness and sin, like a bright spot, like a great reminder.yooAnd there’s no need of much teaching or explanation, he will understand ityooall simply. Do you suppose that the peasants don’t understand? Try readingyoothem the touching story of the fair Esther and the haughty Vashti; or theyoomiraculous story of Jonah in the whale. Don’t forget either the parablesyooof Our Lord, choose especially from the Gospel of St. Luke (that is what Iyoodid), and then from the Acts of the Apostles the conversion of St. Paulyoo(that you mustn’t leave out on any account), and from the _Lives of theyooSaints_, for instance, the life of Alexey, the man of God and, greatest ofyooall, the happy martyr and the seer of God, Mary of Egypt—and you willyoopenetrate their hearts with these simple tales. Give one hour a week to ityooin spite of your poverty, only one little hour. And you will see foryooyourselves that our people is gracious and grateful, and will repay you ayoohundred-fold. Mindful of the kindness of their priest and the moving wordsyoothey have heard from him, they will of their own accord help him in hisyoofields and in his house, and will treat him with more respect thanyoobefore—so that it will even increase his worldly well-being too. The thingyoois so simple that sometimes one is even afraid to put it into words, foryoofear of being laughed at, and yet how true it is! One who does not believeyooin God will not believe in God’s people. He who believes in God’s peopleyoowill see His Holiness too, even though he had not believed in it tillyoothen. Only the people and their future spiritual power will convert ouryooatheists, who have torn themselves away from their native soil.yooyooAnd what is the use of Christ’s words, unless we set an example? Theyoopeople is lost without the Word of God, for its soul is athirst for theyooWord and for all that is good.yooyooIn my youth, long ago, nearly forty years ago, I traveled all over Russiayoowith Father Anfim, collecting funds for our monastery, and we stayed oneyoonight on the bank of a great navigable river with some fishermen. Ayoogood-looking peasant lad, about eighteen, joined us; he had to hurry backyoonext morning to pull a merchant’s barge along the bank. I noticed himyoolooking straight before him with clear and tender eyes. It was a bright,yoowarm, still, July night, a cool mist rose from the broad river, we couldyoohear the plash of a fish, the birds were still, all was hushed andyoobeautiful, everything praying to God. Only we two were not sleeping, theyoolad and I, and we talked of the beauty of this world of God’s and of theyoogreat mystery of it. Every blade of grass, every insect, ant, and goldenyoobee, all so marvelously know their path, though they have notyoointelligence, they bear witness to the mystery of God and continuallyyooaccomplish it themselves. I saw the dear lad’s heart was moved. He told meyoothat he loved the forest and the forest birds. He was a bird-catcher, knewyoothe note of each of them, could call each bird. “I know nothing betteryoothan to be in the forest,” said he, “though all things are good.”yooyoo“Truly,” I answered him, “all things are good and fair, because all isyootruth. Look,” said I, “at the horse, that great beast that is so near toyooman; or the lowly, pensive ox, which feeds him and works for him; look atyootheir faces, what meekness, what devotion to man, who often beats themyoomercilessly. What gentleness, what confidence and what beauty! It’syootouching to know that there’s no sin in them, for all, all except man, isyoosinless, and Christ has been with them before us.”yooyoo“Why,” asked the boy, “is Christ with them too?”yooyoo“It cannot but be so,” said I, “since the Word is for all. All creationyooand all creatures, every leaf is striving to the Word, singing glory toyooGod, weeping to Christ, unconsciously accomplishing this by the mystery ofyootheir sinless life. Yonder,” said I, “in the forest wanders the dreadfulyoobear, fierce and menacing, and yet innocent in it.” And I told him howyooonce a bear came to a great saint who had taken refuge in a tiny cell inyoothe wood. And the great saint pitied him, went up to him without fear andyoogave him a piece of bread. “Go along,” said he, “Christ be with you,” andyoothe savage beast walked away meekly and obediently, doing no harm. And theyoolad was delighted that the bear had walked away without hurting the saint,yooand that Christ was with him too. “Ah,” said he, “how good that is, howyoogood and beautiful is all God’s work!” He sat musing softly and sweetly. Iyoosaw he understood. And he slept beside me a light and sinless sleep. MayyooGod bless youth! And I prayed for him as I went to sleep. Lord, send peaceyooand light to Thy people!yooyooyooyooChapter II. The Duelyooyooyoo_(c) Recollections of Father Zossima’s Youth before he became a Monk. TheyooDuel_yooyooI spent a long time, almost eight years, in the military cadet school atyooPetersburg, and in the novelty of my surroundings there, many of myyoochildish impressions grew dimmer, though I forgot nothing. I picked up soyoomany new habits and opinions that I was transformed into a cruel, absurd,yooalmost savage creature. A surface polish of courtesy and society manners Iyoodid acquire together with the French language.yooyooBut we all, myself included, looked upon the soldiers in our service asyoocattle. I was perhaps worse than the rest in that respect, for I was soyoomuch more impressionable than my companions. By the time we left theyooschool as officers, we were ready to lay down our lives for the honor ofyoothe regiment, but no one of us had any knowledge of the real meaning ofyoohonor, and if any one had known it, he would have been the first toyooridicule it. Drunkenness, debauchery and devilry were what we almostyooprided ourselves on. I don’t say that we were bad by nature, all theseyooyoung men were good fellows, but they behaved badly, and I worst of all.yooWhat made it worse for me was that I had come into my own money, and so Iyooflung myself into a life of pleasure, and plunged headlong into all theyoorecklessness of youth.yooyooI was fond of reading, yet strange to say, the Bible was the one book Iyoonever opened at that time, though I always carried it about with me, and Iyoowas never separated from it; in very truth I was keeping that book “foryoothe day and the hour, for the month and the year,” though I knew it not.yooyooAfter four years of this life, I chanced to be in the town of K. where ouryooregiment was stationed at the time. We found the people of the townyoohospitable, rich and fond of entertainments. I met with a cordialyooreception everywhere, as I was of a lively temperament and was known to beyoowell off, which always goes a long way in the world. And then ayoocircumstance happened which was the beginning of it all.yooyooI formed an attachment to a beautiful and intelligent young girl of nobleyooand lofty character, the daughter of people much respected. They wereyoowell-to-do people of influence and position. They always gave me a cordialyooand friendly reception. I fancied that the young lady looked on me withyoofavor and my heart was aflame at such an idea. I was prevented, however, from making her anyoooffer at the time by my selfishness, I was loath to part with theyooallurements of my free and licentious bachelor life in the heyday of myyooyouth, and with my pockets full of money. Theyooworst of it all was that, as I learned then, the young landowner had beenyooa long while betrothed to her, and I had met him indeed many times in heryoohouse, but blinded by my conceit I had noticed nothing. And thisyooparticularly mortified me; almost everybody had known all about it, whileyooI knew nothing. I was filled with sudden irrepressible fury. With flushedyooface I began recalling how often I had been on the point of declaring myyoolove to her, and as she had not attempted to stop me or to warn me, sheyoomust, I concluded, have been laughing at me all the time. Later on, ofyoocourse, I reflected and remembered that she had been very far fromyoolaughing at me; on the contrary, she used to turn off any love-making onyoomy part with a jest and begin talking of other subjects; but at thatyoomoment I was incapable of reflecting and was all eagerness for revenge. Iyooam surprised to remember that my wrath and revengeful feelings wereyooextremely repugnant to my own nature, for being of an easy temper, I foundyooit difficult to be angry with any one for long, and so I had to workyoomyself up artificially and became at last revolting and absurd.yooyooI waited for an opportunity and succeeded in insulting my “rival” in theyoopresence of a large company. I insulted him on a perfectly extraneousyoopretext, jeering at his opinion upon an important public event—it was inyoothe year 1826(5)—and my jeer was, so people said, clever and effective.yooThen I forced him to ask for an explanation, and behaved so rudely that heyooaccepted my challenge in spite of the vast inequality between us, as I wasyooyounger, a person of no consequence, and of inferior rank. I learnedyooafterwards for a fact that it was from a jealous feeling on his side alsoyoothat my challenge was accepted; he had been rather jealous of me on hisyoowife’s account before their marriage; he fancied now that if he submittedyooto be insulted by me and refused to accept my challenge, and if she heardyooof it, she might begin to despise him and waver in her love for him. Iyoosoon found a second in a comrade, an ensign of our regiment. In those daysyoothough duels were severely punished, yet dueling was a kind of fashionyooamong the officers—so strong and deeply rooted will a brutal prejudiceyoosometimes be.yooyooIt was the end of June, and our meeting was to take place at seven o’clockyoothe next day on the outskirts of the town—and then something happened thatyooin very truth was the turning-point of my life. In the evening, returningyoohome in a savage and brutal humor, I flew into a rage with my orderlyyooAfanasy, and gave him two blows in the face with all my might, so that ityoowas covered with blood. He had not long been in my service and I hadyoostruck him before, but never with such ferocious cruelty. And, believe me,yoothough it’s forty years ago, I recall it now with shame and pain. I wentyooto bed and slept for about three hours; when I waked up the day wasyoobreaking. I got up—I did not want to sleep any more—I went to theyoowindow—opened it, it looked out upon the garden; I saw the sun rising; ityoowas warm and beautiful, the birds were singing.yooyoo“What’s the meaning of it?” I thought. “I feel in my heart as it wereyoosomething vile and shameful. Is it because I am going to shed blood? No,”yooI thought, “I feel it’s not that. Can it be that I am afraid of death,yooafraid of being killed? No, that’s not it, that’s not it at all.”... It all rose before my mind, it all was as it were repeatedyooover again; he stood before me and I was beating him straight on the faceyooand he was holding his arms stiffly down, his head erect, his eyes fixedyooupon me as though on parade. He staggered at every blow and did not evenyoodare to raise his hands to protect himself. That is what a man has beenyoobrought to, and that was a man beating a fellow creature! What a crime! Ityoowas as though a sharp dagger had pierced me right through. I stood as if Iyoowere struck dumb, while the sun was shining, the leaves were rejoicing andyoothe birds were trilling the praise of God.... And then I remembered myyoobrother Markel and what he said on his death-bed to his servants: “My dearyooones, why do you wait on me, why do you love me, am I worth your waitingyooon me?”yooyoo“Yes, am I worth it?” flashed through my mind. “After all what am I worth,yoothat another man, a fellow creature, made in the likeness and image ofyooGod, should serve me?” For the first time in my life this question forcedyooitself upon me. Some, at first a fewyooand afterwards more, began indeed to believe in the truth of his story,yooand they visited me and questioned me with great interest and eagerness,yoofor man loves to see the downfall and disgrace of the righteous.
