But I remember inyoomy prayer to this day, the servant of God, Mihail, who suffered soyoogreatly.yooyooyooyooChapter III. Conversations And Exhortations Of Father Zossimayooyooyoo_(e) The Russian Monk and his possible Significance_yooyooFathers and teachers, what is the monk? In the cultivated world the wordyoois nowadays pronounced by some people with a jeer, and by others it isyooused as a term of abuse, and this contempt for the monk is growing. It isyootrue, alas, it is true, that there are many sluggards, gluttons,yooprofligates and insolent beggars among monks. Educated people point toyoothese: “You are idlers, useless members of society, you live on the laboryooof others, you are shameless beggars.” And yet how many meek and humbleyoomonks there are, yearning for solitude and fervent prayer in peace! Theseyooare less noticed, or passed over in silence. And how surprised men wouldyoobe if I were to say that from these meek monks, who yearn for solitaryyooprayer, the salvation of Russia will come perhaps once more! For they areyooin truth made ready in peace and quiet “for the day and the hour, theyoomonth and the year.” Meanwhile, in their solitude, they keep the image ofyooChrist fair and undefiled, in the purity of God’s truth, from the times ofyoothe Fathers of old, the Apostles and the martyrs. And when the time comesyoothey will show it to the tottering creeds of the world. That is a greatyoothought. That star will rise out of the East.yooyooThat is my view of the monk, and is it false? is it too proud? Look at theyooworldly and all who set themselves up above the people of God, has notyooGod’s image and His truth been distorted in them? They have science; butyooin science there is nothing but what is the object of sense. The spiritualyooworld, the higher part of man’s being is rejected altogether, dismissedyoowith a sort of triumph, even with hatred. The world has proclaimed theyooreign of freedom, especially of late, but what do we see in this freedomyooof theirs? Nothing but slavery and self-destruction! For the world says:yooyoo“You have desires and so satisfy them, for you have the same rights as theyoomost rich and powerful. Don’t be afraid of satisfying them and evenyoomultiply your desires.” That is the modern doctrine of the world. In thatyoothey see freedom. And what follows from this right of multiplication ofyoodesires? In the rich, isolation and spiritual suicide; in the poor, envyyooand murder; for they have been given rights, but have not been shown theyoomeans of satisfying their wants. They maintain that the world is gettingyoomore and more united, more and more bound together in brotherly community,yooas it overcomes distance and sets thoughts flying through the air.yooyooAlas, put no faith in such a bond of union. Interpreting freedom as theyoomultiplication and rapid satisfaction of desires, men distort their ownyoonature, for many senseless and foolish desires and habits and ridiculousyoofancies are fostered in them. They live only for mutual envy, for luxuryyooand ostentation. To have dinners, visits, carriages, rank and slaves toyoowait on one is looked upon as a necessity, for which life, honor and humanyoofeeling are sacrificed, and men even commit suicide if they are unable toyoosatisfy it. We see the same thing among those who are not rich, while theyoopoor drown their unsatisfied need and their envy in drunkenness. But soonyoothey will drink blood instead of wine, they are being led on to it. I askyooyou is such a man free? I knew one “champion of freedom” who told meyoohimself that, when he was deprived of tobacco in prison, he was soyoowretched at the privation that he almost went and betrayed his cause foryoothe sake of getting tobacco again! And such a man says, “I am fighting foryoothe cause of humanity.”yooyooHow can such a one fight? what is he fit for? He is capable perhaps ofyoosome action quickly over, but he cannot hold out long. And it’s no wonderyoothat instead of gaining freedom they have sunk into slavery, and insteadyooof serving the cause of brotherly love and the union of humanity haveyoofallen, on the contrary, into dissension and isolation, as my mysteriousyoovisitor and teacher said to me in my youth. And therefore the idea of theyooservice of humanity, of brotherly love and the solidarity of mankind, isyoomore and more dying out in the world, and indeed this idea is sometimesyootreated with derision. For how can a man shake off his habits? What canyoobecome of him if he is in such bondage to the habit of satisfying theyooinnumerable desires he has created for himself? He is isolated, and whatyooconcern has he with the rest of humanity? They have succeeded inyooaccumulating a greater mass of objects, but the joy in the world has grownyooless.yooyooThe monastic way is very different. Obedience, fasting and prayer areyoolaughed at, yet only through them lies the way to real, true freedom. Iyoocut off my superfluous and unnecessary desires, I subdue my proud andyoowanton will and chastise it with obedience, and with God’s help I attainyoofreedom of spirit and with it spiritual joy. Which is most capable ofyooconceiving a great idea and serving it—the rich man in his isolation oryoothe man who has freed himself from the tyranny of material things andyoohabits? The monk is reproached for his solitude, “You have secludedyooyourself within the walls of the monastery for your own salvation, andyoohave forgotten the brotherly service of humanity!” But we shall see whichyoowill be most zealous in the cause of brotherly love. For it is not we, butyoothey, who are in isolation, though they don’t see that. Of old, leaders ofyoothe people came from among us, and why should they not again? The sameyoomeek and humble ascetics will rise up and go out to work for the greatyoocause. The salvation of Russia comes from the people. And the Russian monkyoohas always been on the side of the people. We are isolated only if theyoopeople are isolated. The people believe as we do, and an unbelievingyooreformer will never do anything in Russia, even if he is sincere in heartyooand a genius. Remember that! The people will meet the atheist and overcomeyoohim, and Russia will be one and orthodox. Take care of the peasant andyooguard his heart. Go on educating him quietly. That’s your duty as monks,yoofor the peasant has God in his heart.yooyoo(_f_) _Of Masters and Servants, and of whether it is possible for them toyoobe Brothers in the Spirit_yooyooOf course, I don’t deny that there is sin in the peasants too. And theyoofire of corruption is spreading visibly, hourly, working from aboveyoodownwards. The spirit of isolation is coming upon the people too.yooMoney-lenders and devourers of the commune are rising up. Already theyoomerchant grows more and more eager for rank, and strives to show himselfyoocultured though he has not a trace of culture, and to this end meanlyyoodespises his old traditions, and is even ashamed of the faith of hisyoofathers. He visits princes, though he is only a peasant corrupted. Theyoopeasants are rotting in drunkenness and cannot shake off the habit. Andyoowhat cruelty to their wives, to their children even! All from drunkenness!yooI’ve seen in the factories children of nine years old, frail, rickety,yoobent and already depraved. The stuffy workshop, the din of machinery, workyooall day long, the vile language and the drink, the drink—is that what ayoolittle child’s heart needs? He needs sunshine, childish play, goodyooexamples all about him, and at least a little love. There must be no moreyooof this, monks, no more torturing of children, rise up and preach that,yoomake haste, make haste!yooyooBut God will save Russia, for though the peasants are corrupted and cannotyoorenounce their filthy sin, yet they know it is cursed by God and that theyyoodo wrong in sinning. So that our people still believe in righteousness,yoohave faith in God and weep tears of devotion.yooyooIt is different with the upper classes. They, following science, want toyoobase justice on reason alone, but not with Christ, as before, and theyyoohave already proclaimed that there is no crime, that there is no sin. Andyoothat’s consistent, for if you have no God what is the meaning of crime? InyooEurope the people are already rising up against the rich with violence,yooand the leaders of the people are everywhere leading them to bloodshed,yooand teaching them that their wrath is righteous. But their “wrath isyooaccursed, for it is cruel.” But God will save Russia as He has saved heryoomany times. Salvation will come from the people, from their faith andyootheir meekness.yooyooFathers and teachers, watch over the people’s faith and this will not be ayoodream. I’ve been struck all my life in our great people by their dignity,yootheir true and seemly dignity. I’ve seen it myself, I can testify to it,yooI’ve seen it and marveled at it, I’ve seen it in spite of the degradedyoosins and poverty-stricken appearance of our peasantry. They are notyooservile, and even after two centuries of serfdom they are free in manneryooand bearing, yet without insolence, and not revengeful and not envious.yoo“You are rich and noble, you are clever and talented, well, be so, Godyoobless you. I have seen it myself, I have known it myself, and,yoowould you believe it, the poorer our Russian peasant is, the moreyoonoticeable is that serene goodness, for the rich among them are for theyoomost part corrupted already, and much of that is due to our carelessnessyooand indifference. I dream of seeing, and seem to see clearly already, our future.yooIt will come to pass, that even the most corrupt of our rich will end byyoobeing ashamed of his riches before the poor, and the poor, seeing hisyoohumility, will understand and give way before him, will respond joyfullyyooand kindly to his honorable shame. If we wereyoobrothers, there would be fraternity, but before that, they will neveryooagree about the division of wealth. We preserve the image of Christ, andyooit will shine forth like a precious diamond to the whole world. So may ityoobe, so may it be!yooyooFathers and teachers, a touching incident befell me once. In my wanderingsyooI met in the town of K. my old orderly, Afanasy. It was eight years sinceyooI had parted from him. He chanced to see me in the market-place,yoorecognized me, ran up to me, and how delighted he was! He simply pouncedyooon me: “Master dear, is it you? Is it really you I see?” He took me homeyoowith him.yooyooHe was no longer in the army, he was married and already had two littleyoochildren. He and his wife earned their living as costermongers in theyoomarket-place. His room was poor, but bright and clean. He made me sityoodown, set the samovar, sent for his wife, as though my appearance were ayoofestival for them. He brought me his children: “Bless them, Father.”yooyoo“Is it for me to bless them? And I explained that to him asyoowell as I could. And what do you think? The man kept gazing at me andyoocould not believe that I, his former master, an officer, was now beforeyoohim in such a guise and position; it made him shed tears.yooyoo“Why are you weeping?” said I, “better rejoice over me, dear friend, whomyooI can never forget, for my path is a glad and joyful one.”yooyooHe did not say much, but kept sighing and shaking his head over meyootenderly.yooyoo“What has became of your fortune?” he asked.yooyoo“I gave it to the monastery,” I answered; “we live in common.”yooyooAfter tea I began saying good-by, and suddenly he brought out half ayoorouble as an offering to the monastery, and another half-rouble I saw himyoothrusting hurriedly into my hand: “That’s for you in your wanderings, ityoomay be of use to you, Father.”yooyooI took his half-rouble, bowed to him and his wife, and went out rejoicing.yooAnd on my way I thought: “Here we are both now, he at home and I on theyooroad, sighing and shaking our heads, no doubt, and yet smiling joyfully inyoothe gladness of our hearts, remembering how God brought about ouryoomeeting.”yooyooI have never seen him again since then. I had been his master and he myyooservant, but now when we exchanged a loving kiss with softened hearts,yoothere was a great human bond between us. I have thought a great deal aboutyoothat, and now what I think is this: Is it so inconceivable that that grandyooand simple-hearted unity might in due time become universal among theyooRussian people? I believe that it will come to pass and that the time isyooat hand.yooyooAnd of servants I will add this: In old days when I was young I was oftenyooangry with servants; “the cook had served something too hot, the orderlyyoohad not brushed my clothes.” But what taught me better then was a thoughtyooof my dear brother’s, which I had heard from him in childhood: “Am I worthyooit, that another should serve me and be ordered about by me in his povertyyooand ignorance?” And I wondered at the time that such simple andyooself-evident ideas should be so slow to occur to our minds.yooyooIt is impossible that there should be no servants in the world, but act soyoothat your servant may be freer in spirit than if he were not a servant.yooAnd why cannot I be a servant to my servant and even let him see it, andyoothat without any pride on my part or any mistrust on his? Why should notyoomy servant be like my own kindred, so that I may take him into my familyyooand rejoice in doing so? Even now this can be done, but it will lead toyoothe grand unity of men in the future, when a man will not seek servantsyoofor himself, or desire to turn his fellow creatures into servants as heyoodoes now, but on the contrary, will long with his whole heart to be theyooservant of all, as the Gospel teaches.yooyooAnd can it be a dream, that in the end man will find his joy only in deedsyooof light and mercy, and not in cruel pleasures as now, in gluttony,yoofornication, ostentation, boasting and envious rivalry of one with theyooother? I firmly believe that it is not and that the time is at hand.yooPeople laugh and ask: “When will that time come and does it look likeyoocoming?” I believe that with Christ’s help we shall accomplish this greatyoothing. And how many ideas there have been on earth in the history of manyoowhich were unthinkable ten years before they appeared! Yet when theiryoodestined hour had come, they came forth and spread over the whole earth.yooSo it will be with us, and our people will shine forth in the world, andyooall men will say: “The stone which the builders rejected has become theyoocorner-stone of the building.”yooyooAnd we may ask the scornful themselves: If our hope is a dream, when willyooyou build up your edifice and order things justly by your intellect alone,yoowithout Christ? If they declare that it is they who are advancing towardsyoounity, only the most simple-hearted among them believe it, so that one mayyoopositively marvel at such simplicity. Of a truth, they have more fantasticyoodreams than we. They aim at justice, but, denying Christ, they will end byyooflooding the earth with blood, for blood cries out for blood, and he thatyootaketh up the sword shall perish by the sword. And if it were not foryooChrist’s covenant, they would slaughter one another down to the last twoyoomen on earth. And those two last men would not be able to restrain eachyooother in their pride, and the one would slay the other and then himself.yooAnd that would come to pass, were it not for the promise of Christ thatyoofor the sake of the humble and meek the days shall be shortened.yooyooWhile I was still wearing an officer’s uniform after my duel, I talkedyooabout servants in general society, and I remember every one was amazed atyoome. “What!” they asked, “are we to make our servants sit down on the sofayooand offer them tea?” And I answered them: “Why not, sometimes at least?”yooEvery one laughed. Their question was frivolous and my answer was notyooclear; but the thought in it was to some extent right.yooyoo(_g_) _Of Prayer, of Love, and of Contact with other Worlds_yooyooYoung man, be not forgetful of prayer. Every time you pray, if your prayeryoois sincere, there will be new feeling and new meaning in it, which willyoogive you fresh courage, and you will understand that prayer is anyooeducation. Remember, too, every day, and whenever you can, repeat toyooyourself, “Lord, have mercy on all who appear before Thee to-day.” Foryooevery hour and every moment thousands of men leave life on this earth, andyootheir souls appear before God. And how many of them depart in solitude,yoounknown, sad, dejected that no one mourns for them or even knows whetheryoothey have lived or not! And behold, from the other end of the earthyooperhaps, your prayer for their rest will rise up to God though you knewyoothem not nor they you. How touching it must be to a soul standing in dreadyoobefore the Lord to feel at that instant that, for him too, there is one toyoopray, that there is a fellow creature left on earth to love him too! AndyooGod will look on you both more graciously, for if you have had so muchyoopity on him, how much will He have pity Who is infinitely more loving andyoomerciful than you! And He will forgive him for your sake.yooyooBrothers, have no fear of men’s sin. Love a man even in his sin, for thatyoois the semblance of Divine Love and is the highest love on earth. Love allyooGod’s creation, the whole and every grain of sand in it. Love every leaf,yooevery ray of God’s light. Love the animals, love the plants, loveyooeverything. If you love everything, you will perceive the divine mysteryyooin things. Once you perceive it, you will begin to comprehend it betteryooevery day. And you will come at last to love the whole world with anyooall-embracing love. Love the animals: God has given them the rudiments ofyoothought and joy untroubled. Do not trouble it, don’t harass them, don’tyoodeprive them of their happiness, don’t work against God’s intent. Man, doyoonot pride yourself on superiority to the animals; they are without sin,yooand you, with your greatness, defile the earth by your appearance on it,yooand leave the traces of your foulness after you—alas, it is true of almostyooevery one of us! Love children especially, for they too are sinless likeyoothe angels; they live to soften and purify our hearts and as it were toyooguide us. Woe to him who offends a child! Father Anfim taught me to loveyoochildren. The kind, silent man used often on our wanderings to spend theyoofarthings given us on sweets and cakes for the children. He could not passyooby a child without emotion. That’s the nature of the man.yooyooAt some thoughts one stands perplexed, especially at the sight of men’syoosin, and wonders whether one should use force or humble love. Alwaysyoodecide to use humble love. If you resolve on that once for all, you mayyoosubdue the whole world. Loving humility is marvelously strong, theyoostrongest of all things, and there is nothing else like it.yooyooEvery day and every hour, every minute, walk round yourself and watchyooyourself, and see that your image is a seemly one. You pass by a littleyoochild, you pass by, spiteful, with ugly words, with wrathful heart; youyoomay not have noticed the child, but he has seen you, and your image,yoounseemly and ignoble, may remain in his defenseless heart. You don’t knowyooit, but you may have sown an evil seed in him and it may grow, and allyoobecause you were not careful before the child, because you did not fosteryooin yourself a careful, actively benevolent love. Brothers, love is ayooteacher; but one must know how to acquire it, for it is hard to acquire,yooit is dearly bought, it is won slowly by long labor. For we must love notyooonly occasionally, for a moment, but for ever. Every one can loveyoooccasionally, even the wicked can.yooyooMy brother asked the birds to forgive him; that sounds senseless, but ityoois right; for all is like an ocean, all is flowing and blending; a touchyooin one place sets up movement at the other end of the earth. It may beyoosenseless to beg forgiveness of the birds, but birds would be happier atyooyour side—a little happier, anyway—and children and all animals, if youyoowere nobler than you are now. It’s all like an ocean, I tell you. Then youyoowould pray to the birds too, consumed by an all-embracing love, in a sortyooof transport, and pray that they too will forgive you your sin. Treasureyoothis ecstasy, however senseless it may seem to men.yooyooMy friends, pray to God for gladness. Be glad as children, as the birds ofyooheaven. And let not the sin of men confound you in your doings. Fear notyoothat it will wear away your work and hinder its being accomplished. Do notyoosay, “Sin is mighty, wickedness is mighty, evil environment is mighty, andyoowe are lonely and helpless, and evil environment is wearing us away andyoohindering our good work from being done.” Fly from that dejection,yoochildren! There is only one means of salvation, then take yourself andyoomake yourself responsible for all men’s sins, that is the truth, you know,yoofriends, for as soon as you sincerely make yourself responsible foryooeverything and for all men, you will see at once that it is really so, andyoothat you are to blame for every one and for all things. But throwing youryooown indolence and impotence on others you will end by sharing the pride ofyooSatan and murmuring against God.yooyooOf the pride of Satan what I think is this: it is hard for us on earth toyoocomprehend it, and therefore it is so easy to fall into error and to shareyooit, even imagining that we are doing something grand and fine. Indeed,yoomany of the strongest feelings and movements of our nature we cannotyoocomprehend on earth. Let not that be a stumbling-block, and think not thatyooit may serve as a justification to you for anything. For the Eternal Judgeyooasks of you what you can comprehend and not what you cannot. You will knowyoothat yourself hereafter, for you will behold all things truly then andyoowill not dispute them. On earth, indeed, we are as it were astray, and ifyooit were not for the precious image of Christ before us, we should beyooundone and altogether lost, as was the human race before the flood. Muchyooon earth is hidden from us, but to make up for that we have been given ayooprecious mystic sense of our living bond with the other world, with theyoohigher heavenly world, and the roots of our thoughts and feelings are notyoohere but in other worlds. That is why the philosophers say that we cannotyooapprehend the reality of things on earth.yooyooGod took seeds from different worlds and sowed them on this earth, and Hisyoogarden grew up and everything came up that could come up, but what growsyoolives and is alive only through the feeling of its contact with otheryoomysterious worlds. If that feeling grows weak or is destroyed in you, theyooheavenly growth will die away in you. Then you will be indifferent to lifeyooand even grow to hate it. That’s what I think.yooyoo_(h) Can a Man judge his Fellow Creatures? Faith to the End_yooyooRemember particularly that you cannot be a judge of any one. For no oneyoocan judge a criminal, until he recognizes that he is just such a criminalyooas the man standing before him, and that he perhaps is more than all menyooto blame for that crime. When he understands that, he will be able to be ayoojudge. Though that sounds absurd, it is true. If I had been righteousyoomyself, perhaps there would have been no criminal standing before me. Ifyooyou can take upon yourself the crime of the criminal your heart isyoojudging, take it at once, suffer for him yourself, and let him go withoutyooreproach. And even if the law itself makes you his judge, act in the sameyoospirit so far as possible, for he will go away and condemn himself moreyoobitterly than you have done. If you remember in the night as you go to sleep, “Iyoohave not done what I ought to have done,” rise up at once and do it. Ifyoothe people around you are spiteful and callous and will not hear you, fallyoodown before them and beg their forgiveness; for in truth you are to blameyoofor their not wanting to hear you. And if you cannot speak to them inyootheir bitterness, serve them in silence and in humility, never losingyoohope. Accept that suffering and bear ityooand your heart will find comfort, and you will understand that you too areyooguilty, for you might have been a light to the evil-doers, even as the oneyooman sinless, and you were not a light to them. If you had been a light,yooyou would have lightened the path for others too, and the evil-doer mightyooperhaps have been saved by your light from his sin. Men reject their prophets and slayyoothem, but they love their martyrs and honor those whom they have slain.yooYou are working for the whole, you are acting for the future. Seek noyooreward, for great is your reward on this earth: the spiritual joy which isyooonly vouchsafed to the righteous man. Fear not the great nor the mighty,yoobut be wise and ever serene. Don’t be ashamed ofyoothat ecstasy, prize it, for it is a gift of God and a great one; it is notyoogiven to many but only to the elect.yooyoo_(i) Of Hell and Hell Fire, a Mystic Reflection_yooyooFathers and teachers, I ponder, “What is hell?” I maintain that it is theyoosuffering of being unable to love. Once in infinite existence,yooimmeasurable in time and space, a spiritual creature was given on hisyoocoming to earth, the power of saying, “I am and I love.” Once, only once,yoothere was given him a moment of active _living_ love, and for that wasyooearthly life given him, and with it times and seasons. And that happyyoocreature rejected the priceless gift, prized it and loved it not, scornedyooit and remained callous. Such a one, having left the earth, sees Abraham’syoobosom and talks with Abraham as we are told in the parable of the rich manyooand Lazarus, and beholds heaven and can go up to the Lord. But that isyoojust his torment, to rise up to the Lord without ever having loved, to beyoobrought close to those who have loved when he has despised their love. Foryoohe sees clearly and says to himself, “Now I have understanding, and thoughyooI now thirst to love, there will be nothing great, no sacrifice in myyoolove, for my earthly life is over, and Abraham will not come even with ayoodrop of living water (that is the gift of earthly active life) to cool theyoofiery thirst of spiritual love which burns in me now, though I despised ityooon earth; there is no more life for me and will be no more time! Evenyoothough I would gladly give my life for others, it can never be, for thatyoolife is passed which can be sacrificed for love, and now there is a gulfyoofixed between that life and this existence.”yooyooThey talk of hell fire in the material sense. I don’t go into that mysteryyooand I shun it. But I think if there were fire in material sense, theyyoowould be glad of it, for I imagine that in material agony, their stillyoogreater spiritual agony would be forgotten for a moment. Moreover, thatyoospiritual agony cannot be taken from them, for that suffering is notyooexternal but within them. And if it could be taken from them, I think ityoowould be bitterer still for the unhappy creatures. For even if theyoorighteous in Paradise forgave them, beholding their torments, and calledyoothem up to heaven in their infinite love, they would only multiply theiryootorments, for they would arouse in them still more keenly a flaming thirstyoofor responsive, active and grateful love which is now impossible. In theyootimidity of my heart I imagine, however, that the very recognition of thisyooimpossibility would serve at last to console them. For accepting the loveyooof the righteous together with the impossibility of repaying it, by thisyoosubmissiveness and the effect of this humility, they will attain at last,yooas it were, to a certain semblance of that active love which they scornedyooin life, to something like its outward expression.... I am sorry, friendsyooand brothers, that I cannot express this clearly. But woe to those whoyoohave slain themselves on earth, woe to the suicides! I believe that thereyoocan be none more miserable then they. They tell us that it is a sin toyoopray for them and outwardly the Church, as it were, renounces them, but inyoomy secret heart I believe that we may pray even for them. Love can neveryoobe an offense to Christ. For such as those I have prayed inwardly all myyoolife, I confess it, fathers and teachers, and even now I pray for themyooevery day.yooyooOh, there are some who remain proud and fierce even in hell, in spite ofyootheir certain knowledge and contemplation of the absolute truth; there areyoosome fearful ones who have given themselves over to Satan and his proudyoospirit entirely. For such, hell is voluntary and ever consuming; they areyootortured by their own choice. For they have cursed themselves, cursing Godyooand life. They live upon their vindictive pride like a starving man in theyoodesert sucking blood out of his own body. But they are never satisfied,yooand they refuse forgiveness, they curse God Who calls them. They cannotyoobehold the living God without hatred, and they cry out that the God ofyoolife should be annihilated, that God should destroy Himself and His ownyoocreation. And they will burn in the fire of their own wrath for ever andyooyearn for death and annihilation. But they will not attain to death....yooyoo                  -------------------------------------yooyooHere Alexey Fyodorovitch Karamazov’s manuscript ends. I repeat, it isyooincomplete and fragmentary. Biographical details, for instance, cover onlyyooFather Zossima’s earliest youth. Of his teaching and opinions we findyoobrought together sayings evidently uttered on very different occasions.yooHis utterances during the last few hours have not been kept separate fromyoothe rest, but their general character can be gathered from what we have inyooAlexey Fyodorovitch’s manuscript.yooyooThe elder’s death came in the end quite unexpectedly. For although thoseyoowho were gathered about him that last evening realized that his death wasyooapproaching, yet it was difficult to imagine that it would come soyoosuddenly. On the contrary, his friends, as I observed already, seeing himyoothat night apparently so cheerful and talkative, were convinced that thereyoowas at least a temporary change for the better in his condition. Even fiveyoominutes before his death, they said afterwards wonderingly, it wasyooimpossible to foresee it. He seemed suddenly to feel an acute pain in hisyoochest, he turned pale and pressed his hands to his heart. All rose fromyootheir seats and hastened to him. But though suffering, he still looked atyoothem with a smile, sank slowly from his chair on to his knees, then bowedyoohis face to the ground, stretched out his arms and as though in joyfulyooecstasy, praying and kissing the ground, quietly and joyfully gave up hisyoosoul to God.yooyooThe news of his death spread at once through the hermitage and reached theyoomonastery. The nearest friends of the deceased and those whose duty it wasyoofrom their position began to lay out the corpse according to the ancientyooritual, and all the monks gathered together in the church. And before dawnyoothe news of the death reached the town. By the morning all the town wasyootalking of the event, and crowds were flocking from the town to theyoomonastery. But this subject will be treated in the next book; I will onlyyooadd here that before a day had passed something happened so unexpected, soyoostrange, upsetting, and bewildering in its effect on the monks and theyootownspeople, that after all these years, that day of general suspense isyoostill vividly remembered in the town.yooyooyooyooyooyooPART IIIyooyooyooyooyooBook VII. AlyoshayooyooyooyooChapter I. The Breath Of CorruptionyooyooyooThe body of Father Zossima was prepared for burial according to theyooestablished ritual. As is well known, the bodies of dead monks and hermitsyooare not washed. In the words of the Church Ritual: “If any one of theyoomonks depart in the Lord, the monk designated (that is, whose office ityoois) shall wipe the body with warm water, making first the sign of theyoocross with a sponge on the forehead of the deceased, on the breast, on theyoohands and feet and on the knees, and that is enough.” All this was done byyooFather Païssy, who then clothed the deceased in his monastic garb andyoowrapped him in his cloak, which was, according to custom, somewhat slit toyooallow of its being folded about him in the form of a cross. On his head heyooput a hood with an eight-cornered cross. The hood was left open and theyoodead man’s face was covered with black gauze. In his hands was put an ikonyooof the Saviour. Towards morning he was put in the coffin which had beenyoomade ready long before. It was decided to leave the coffin all day in theyoocell, in the larger room in which the elder used to receive his visitorsyooand fellow monks. As the deceased was a priest and monk of the strictestyoorule, the Gospel, not the Psalter, had to be read over his body by monksyooin holy orders. The reading was begun by Father Iosif immediately afteryoothe requiem service. Father Païssy desired later on to read the Gospel allyooday and night over his dead friend, but for the present he, as well as theyooFather Superintendent of the Hermitage, was very busy and occupied, foryoosomething extraordinary, an unheard-of, even “unseemly” excitement andyooimpatient expectation began to be apparent in the monks, and the visitorsyoofrom the monastery hostels, and the crowds of people flocking from theyootown. And as time went on, this grew more and more marked. Both theyooSuperintendent and Father Païssy did their utmost to calm the generalyoobustle and agitation.yooyooWhen it was fully daylight, some people began bringing their sick, in mostyoocases children, with them from the town—as though they had been waitingyooexpressly for this moment to do so, evidently persuaded that the deadyooelder’s remains had a power of healing, which would be immediately madeyoomanifest in accordance with their faith. It was only then apparent howyoounquestionably every one in our town had accepted Father Zossima duringyoohis lifetime as a great saint. And those who came were far from being allyooof the humbler classes.yooyooThis intense expectation on the part of believers displayed with suchyoohaste, such openness, even with impatience and almost insistence,yooimpressed Father Païssy as unseemly. Though he had long foreseen somethingyooof the sort, the actual manifestation of the feeling was beyond anythingyoohe had looked for. When he came across any of the monks who displayed thisyooexcitement, Father Païssy began to reprove them. “Such immediateyooexpectation of something extraordinary,” he said, “shows a levity,yoopossible to worldly people but unseemly in us.”yooyooBut little attention was paid him and Father Païssy noticed it uneasily.yooYet he himself (if the whole truth must be told), secretly at the bottomyooof his heart, cherished almost the same hopes and could not but be awareyooof it, though he was indignant at the too impatient expectation aroundyoohim, and saw in it light-mindedness and vanity. In the crowd in the dead man’s cell heyoonoticed with inward aversion (for which he immediately reproached himself)yoothe presence of Rakitin and of the monk from Obdorsk, who was stillyoostaying in the monastery. Of both of them Father Païssy felt for someyooreason suddenly suspicious—though, indeed, he might well have felt theyoosame about others.yooyooThe monk from Obdorsk was conspicuous as the most fussy in the excitedyoocrowd. He was to be seen everywhere; everywhere he was asking questions,yooeverywhere he was listening, on all sides he was whispering with ayoopeculiar, mysterious air. His expression showed the greatest impatienceyooand even a sort of irritation.yooyooAs for Rakitin, he, as appeared later, had come so early to the hermitageyooat the special request of Madame Hohlakov. He was particularlyyooclever in getting round people and assuming whatever part he thought mostyooto their taste, if he detected the slightest advantage to himself fromyoodoing so.yooyooIt was a bright, clear day, and many of the visitors were thronging aboutyoothe tombs, which were particularly numerous round the church and scatteredyoohere and there about the hermitage. As he walked round the hermitage,yooFather Païssy remembered Alyosha and that he had not seen him for someyootime, not since the night. And he had no sooner thought of him than he atyooonce noticed him in the farthest corner of the hermitage garden, sittingyooon the tombstone of a monk who had been famous long ago for hisyoosaintliness. He sat with his back to the hermitage and his face to theyoowall, and seemed to be hiding behind the tombstone. When before dawn they laid FatheryooZossima’s body in the coffin and brought it into the front room, theyooquestion of opening the windows was raised among those who were around theyoocoffin. But this suggestion made casually by some one was unanswered andyooalmost unnoticed. Some of those present may perhaps have inwardly noticedyooit, only to reflect that the anticipation of decay and corruption from theyoobody of such a saint was an actual absurdity, calling for compassion (ifyoonot a smile) for the lack of faith and the frivolity it implied. For theyyooexpected something quite different.yooyooAnd, behold, soon after midday there were signs of something, at firstyooonly observed in silence by those who came in and out and were evidentlyyooeach afraid to communicate the thought in his mind. In all the past history of our monastery, no such scandalyoocould be recalled, and in no other circumstances could such a scandal haveyoobeen possible, as showed itself in unseemly disorder immediately afteryoothis discovery among the very monks themselves. Afterwards, even manyyooyears afterwards, some sensible monks were amazed and horrified, when theyyoorecalled that day, that the scandal could have reached such proportions.yooFor in the past, monks of very holy life had died, God-fearing old men,yoowhose saintliness was acknowledged by all, yet from their humble coffins,yootoo, the breath of corruption had come, naturally, as from all deadyoobodies, but that had caused no scandal nor even the slightest excitement.yooOf course there had been, in former times, saints in the monastery whoseyoomemory was carefully preserved and whose relics, according to tradition,yooshowed no signs of corruption. This fact was regarded by the monks asyootouching and mysterious, and the tradition of it was cherished asyoosomething blessed and miraculous, and as a promise, by God’s grace, ofyoostill greater glory from their tombs in the future.yooyooOne such, whose memory was particularly cherished, was an old monk, Job,yoowho had died seventy years before at the age of a hundred and five. He hadyoobeen a celebrated ascetic, rigid in fasting and silence, and his tomb wasyoopointed out to all visitors on their arrival with peculiar respect andyoomysterious hints of great hopes connected with it. (That was the very tombyooon which Father Païssy had found Alyosha sitting in the morning.) Anotheryoomemory cherished in the monastery was that of the famous Father Varsonofy,yoowho was only recently dead and had preceded Father Zossima in theyooeldership. He was reverenced during his lifetime as a crazy saint by allyoothe pilgrims to the monastery. That, I believe, wasyoowhy many people were extremely delighted at the smell of decompositionyoowhich came so quickly, for not a day had passed since his death. At theyoosame time there were some among those who had been hitherto reverentlyyoodevoted to the elder, who were almost mortified and personally affrontedyooby this incident. This was how the thing happened.yooyooAs soon as signs of decomposition had begun to appear, the whole aspect ofyoothe monks betrayed their secret motives in entering the cell. A Critical MomentyooyooyooFather Païssy, of course, was not wrong when he decided that his “dearyooboy” would come back again. Perhaps indeed, to some extent, he penetratedyoowith insight into the true meaning of Alyosha’s spiritual condition. Yet Iyoomust frankly own that it would be very difficult for me to give a clearyooaccount of that strange, vague moment in the life of the young hero I loveyooso much. To Father Païssy’s sorrowful question, “Are you too with those ofyoolittle faith?” I could of course confidently answer for Alyosha, “No, heyoois not with those of little faith. Quite the contrary.” Indeed, all hisyootrouble came from the fact that he was of great faith. But still theyootrouble was there and was so agonizing that even long afterwards Alyoshayoothought of that sorrowful day as one of the bitterest and most fatal daysyooof his life. An OnionyooyooyooGrushenka lived in the busiest part of the town, near the cathedralyoosquare, in a small wooden lodge in the courtyard belonging to the house ofyoothe widow Morozov. Othello’s soul was shattered and his whole outlook clouded simplyyoobecause _his ideal was destroyed_. But Othello did not begin hiding,yoospying, peeping. He was trustful, on the contrary. But here sheyoolooked at him very affectionately: before Mitya’s arrival, she had beenyoomaking much of him, but he seemed somehow to be unmoved by it. He was ayooboy, not over twenty, dressed like a dandy, with a very charmingyoofair-skinned face, and splendid thick, fair hair. From his fair faceyoolooked out beautiful pale blue eyes, with an intelligent and sometimesyooeven deep expression, beyond his age indeed, although the young manyoosometimes looked and talked quite like a child, and was not at all ashamedyooof it, even when he was aware of it himself. As a rule he was veryyoowillful, even capricious, though always friendly. Sometimes there wasyoosomething fixed and obstinate in his expression. He would look at you andyoolisten, seeming all the while to be persistently dreaming over somethingyooelse. Often he was listless and lazy, at other times he would growyooexcited, sometimes, apparently, over the most trivial matters.yooyoo“Only imagine, I’ve been taking him about with me for the last four days,”yoohe went on, indolently drawling his words, quite naturally though, withoutyoothe slightest affectation. “Ever since your brother, do you remember,yooshoved him off the carriage and sent him flying. That made me take anyoointerest in him at the time, and I took him into the country, but he keepsyootalking such rot I’m ashamed to be with him. I’m taking him back.”yooyoo“The gentleman has not seen Polish ladies, and says what is impossible,”yoothe Pole with the pipe observed to Maximov.yooyooHe spoke Russian fairly well, much better, anyway, than he pretended. Ifyoohe used Russian words, he always distorted them into a Polish form.yooyoo“But I was married to a Polish lady myself,” tittered Maximov.yooyoo“But did you serve in the cavalry? You were talking about the cavalry.yooWere you a cavalry officer?” put in Kalganov at once.yooyoo“Was he a cavalry officer indeed? They allow it ... and next day the Uhlan comesyooand offers her his hand.... That’s how it is ... offers her his hand, heyoohe!” Maximov ended, tittering.yooyoo“The _pan_ is a _lajdak_!” the tall Pole on the chair growled suddenly andyoocrossed one leg over the other. The Evidence Of The Witnesses. The BabeyooyooyooThe examination of the witnesses began. But we will not continue our storyyooin such detail as before. He could have made them stand side byyooside and played soldiers with them, or sent them hiding all over theyoohouse. He had done so more than once before and was not above doing it, soyoomuch so that a report once spread at school that Krassotkin played horsesyoowith the little lodgers at home, prancing with his head on one side like ayootrace-horse. But Krassotkin haughtily parried this thrust, pointing outyoothat to play horses with boys of one’s own age, boys of thirteen, wouldyoocertainly be disgraceful “at this date,” but that he did it for the sakeyooof “the kids” because he liked them, and no one had a right to call him toyooaccount for his feelings. The two “kids” adored him.yooyooBut on this occasion he was in no mood for games. He had very importantyoobusiness of his own before him, something almost mysterious. Meanwhileyootime was passing and Agafya, with whom he could have left the children,yoowould not come back from market. He had several times already crossed theyoopassage, opened the door of the lodgers’ room and looked anxiously at “theyookids” who were sitting over the book, as he had bidden them. Every time heyooopened the door they grinned at him, hoping he would come in and would doyoosomething delightful and amusing. But Kolya was bothered and did not goyooin.yooyooAt last it struck eleven and he made up his mind, once for all, that ifyoothat “damned” Agafya did not come back within ten minutes he should go outyoowithout waiting for her, making “the kids” promise, of course, to be braveyoowhen he was away, not to be naughty, not to cry from fright. With thisyooidea he put on his wadded winter overcoat with its catskin fur collar,yooslung his satchel round his shoulder, and, regardless of his mother’syooconstantly reiterated entreaties that he would always put on goloshes inyoosuch cold weather, he looked at them contemptuously as he crossed the hallyooand went out with only his boots on. Perezvon, seeing him in his outdooryooclothes, began tapping nervously, yet vigorously, on the floor with hisyootail. Twitching all over, he even uttered a plaintive whine. But Kolya,yooseeing his dog’s passionate excitement, decided that it was a breach ofyoodiscipline, kept him for another minute under the bench, and only when heyoohad opened the door into the passage, whistled for him. The dog leapt upyoolike a mad creature and rushed bounding before him rapturously.yooyooKolya opened the door to peep at “the kids.” They were both sitting asyoobefore at the table, not reading but warmly disputing about something. Theyoochildren often argued together about various exciting problems of life,yooand Nastya, being the elder, always got the best of it. If Kostya did notyooagree with her, he almost always appealed to Kolya Krassotkin, and hisyooverdict was regarded as infallible by both of them. The children saw he was listening and that made them disputeyoowith even greater energy.yooyoo“I shall never, never believe,” Nastya prattled, “that the old women findyoobabies among the cabbages in the kitchen-garden. It’s winter now and thereyooare no cabbages, and so the old woman couldn’t have taken Katerina ayoodaughter.”yooyooKolya whistled to himself.yooyoo“Or perhaps they do bring babies from somewhere, but only to those who areyoomarried.”yooyooKostya stared at Nastya and listened, pondering profoundly.yooyoo“Nastya, how silly you are!” he said at last, firmly and calmly. “How canyooKaterina have a baby when she isn’t married?”yooyooNastya was exasperated.yooyoo“You know nothing about it,” she snapped irritably. “Perhaps she has ayoohusband, only he is in prison, so now she’s got a baby.”yooyoo“But is her husband in prison?” the matter-of-fact Kostya inquiredyoogravely.yooyoo“Or, I tell you what,” Nastya interrupted impulsively, completelyyoorejecting and forgetting her first hypothesis. “She hasn’t a husband, youyooare right there, but she wants to be married, and so she’s been thinkingyooof getting married, and thinking and thinking of it till now she’s got it,yoothat is, not a husband but a baby.”yooyoo“Well, perhaps so,” Kostya agreed, entirely vanquished. “But you didn’tyoosay so before. Their smiling faces showedyoosigns of uneasiness, but they did not yet fully grasp what was expected ofyoothem.yooyoo“You won’t be naughty while I am gone? He was blind in his right eye, and his left ear wasyootorn. He whined and jumped, stood and walked on his hind legs, lay on hisyooback with his paws in the air, rigid as though he were dead. You want a whipping for saying such things, that’s what you want!”yooyooyooyooChapter III. The SchoolboyyooyooyooBut Kolya did not hear her. At last he could go out. A Judicial ErroryooyooyooyooChapter I. But in front of the balustrade ayoofew chairs had been placed for witnesses who remained in the court afteryoogiving their evidence.yooyooAt ten o’clock the three judges arrived—the President, one honoraryyoojustice of the peace, and one other. The prosecutor, of course, enteredyooimmediately after. The President was a short, stout, thick-set man ofyoofifty, with a dyspeptic complexion, dark hair turning gray and cut short,yooand a red ribbon, of what Order I don’t remember. The prosecutor struck meyooand the others, too, as looking particularly pale, almost green. His faceyooseemed to have grown suddenly thinner, perhaps in a single night, for Iyoohad seen him looking as usual only two days before. The President beganyoowith asking the court whether all the jury were present.yooyooBut I see I can’t go on like this, partly because some things I did notyoohear, others I did not notice, and others I have forgotten, but most ofyooall because, as I have said before, I have literally no time or space toyoomention everything that was said and done. I remember, long before the trial, questions wereyoocontinually asked with some surprise, especially by ladies: “Can such ayoodelicate, complex and psychological case be submitted for decision toyoopetty officials and even peasants?” and “What can an official, still moreyooa peasant, understand in such an affair?” All the four officials in theyoojury were, in fact, men of no consequence and of low rank. Except one whoyoowas rather younger, they were gray-headed men, little known in society,yoowho had vegetated on a pitiful salary, and who probably had elderly,yoounpresentable wives and crowds of children, perhaps even without shoes andyoostockings. At most, they spent their leisure over cards and, of course,yoohad never read a single book. The two merchants looked respectable, butyoowere strangely silent and stolid. One of them was close-shaven, and wasyoodressed in European style; the other had a small, gray beard, and wore ayoored ribbon with some sort of a medal upon it on his neck. There is no needyooto speak of the artisans and the peasants. The artisans ofyooSkotoprigonyevsk are almost peasants, and even work on the land. Two ofyoothem also wore European dress, and, perhaps for that reason, were dirtieryooand more uninviting-looking than the others. I don’t quite remember how he described him. The court usheryoowas told to bring in the prisoner, and Mitya made his appearance. Thereyoowas a hush through the court. One could have heard a fly. I don’t know howyooit was with others, but Mitya made a most unfavorable impression on me. Heyoolooked an awful dandy in a brand-new frock-coat. After an exhortation from theyoopriest and the President, the witnesses were led away and were made to sityooas far as possible apart from one another. Then they began calling them upyooone by one.yooyooyooyooChapter II. Dangerous WitnessesyooyooyooI do not know whether the witnesses for the defense and for theyooprosecution were separated into groups by the President, and whether ityoowas arranged to call them in a certain order. But no doubt it was so. Iyooonly know that the witnesses for the prosecution were called first. Iyoorepeat I don’t intend to describe all the questions step by step. Besides,yoomy account would be to some extent superfluous, because in the speechesyoofor the prosecution and for the defense the whole course of the evidenceyoowas brought together and set in a strong and significant light, and I tookyoodown parts of those two remarkable speeches in full, and will quote themyooin due course, together with one extraordinary and quite unexpectedyooepisode, which occurred before the final speeches, and undoubtedlyyooinfluenced the sinister and fatal outcome of the trial.yooyooI will only observe that from the first moments of the trial one peculiaryoocharacteristic of the case was conspicuous and observed by all, that is,yoothe overwhelming strength of the prosecution as compared with theyooarguments the defense had to rely upon. Every one realized it from theyoofirst moment that the facts began to group themselves round a singleyoopoint, and the whole horrible and bloody crime was gradually revealed.yooEvery one, perhaps, felt from the first that the case was beyond dispute,yoothat there was no doubt about it, that there could be really noyoodiscussion, and that the defense was only a matter of form, and that theyooprisoner was guilty, obviously and conclusively guilty. What’s more, I believe they would have been mortified if hisyooguilt had not been so firmly established, as that would have lessened theyooeffect of the closing scene of the criminal’s acquittal. That he would beyooacquitted, all the ladies, strange to say, were firmly persuaded up to theyoovery last moment. “He is guilty, but he will be acquitted, from motives ofyoohumanity, in accordance with the new ideas, the new sentiments that hadyoocome into fashion,” and so on, and so on. The Medical Experts And A Pound Of NutsyooyooyooThe evidence of the medical experts, too, was of little use to theyooprisoner. And it appeared later that Fetyukovitch had not reckoned muchyooupon it. The Galloping Troika. The End Of The Prosecutor’s Speech.yooyooyooIppolit Kirillovitch had chosen the historical method of exposition,yoobeloved by all nervous orators, who find in its limitation a check onyootheir own eager rhetoric. The guilt of this harassed and desperate manyoostood out clear and convincing, when the facts were brought together.yooyoo“What need had he of precaution? Two or three times he almost confessed,yoohinted at it, all but spoke out.” (Then followed the evidence given byyoowitnesses.) “He even cried out to the peasant who drove him, ‘Do you know,yooyou are driving a murderer!’ But it was impossible for him to speak out,yoohe had to get to Mokroe and there to finish his romance. An Argument That Cuts Both WaysyooyooyooAll was hushed as the first words of the famous orator rang out. The eyesyooof the audience were fastened upon him. He began very simply and directly,yoowith an air of conviction, but not the slightest trace of conceit. He madeyoono attempt at eloquence, at pathos, or emotional phrases. He was like ayooman speaking in a circle of intimate and sympathetic friends. His voiceyoowas a fine one, sonorous and sympathetic, and there was something genuineyooand simple in the very sound of it. But every one realized at once thatyoothe speaker might suddenly rise to genuine pathos and “pierce the heartyoowith untold power.” His language was perhaps more irregular than IppolityooKirillovitch’s, but he spoke without long phrases, and indeed, with moreyooprecision. One thing did not please the ladies: he kept bending forward,yooespecially at the beginning of his speech, not exactly bowing, but asyoothough he were about to dart at his listeners, bending his long spine inyoohalf, as though there were a spring in the middle that enabled him to bendyooalmost at right angles.yooyooAt the beginning of his speech he spoke rather disconnectedly, withoutyoosystem, one may say, dealing with facts separately, though, at the end,yoothese facts formed a whole. His speech might be divided into two parts,yoothe first consisting of criticism in refutation of the charge, sometimesyoomalicious and sarcastic. But in the second half he suddenly changed hisyootone, and even his manner, and at once rose to pathos. The audience seemedyooon the look-out for it, and quivered with enthusiasm.yooyooHe went straight to the point, and began by saying that although heyoopracticed in Petersburg, he had more than once visited provincial towns toyoodefend prisoners, of whose innocence he had a conviction or at least ayoopreconceived idea. “That is what has happened to me in the present case,”yoohe explained. “From the very first accounts in the newspapers I was struckyooby something which strongly prepossessed me in the prisoner’s favor. Whatyoointerested me most was a fact which often occurs in legal practice, butyoorarely, I think, in such an extreme and peculiar form as in the presentyoocase. I ought to formulate that peculiarity only at the end of my speech,yoobut I will do so at the very beginning, for it is my weakness to go toyoowork directly, not keeping my effects in reserve and economizing myyoomaterial. That may be imprudent on my part, but at least it’s sincere.yooWhat I have in my mind is this: there is an overwhelming chain of evidenceyooagainst the prisoner, and at the same time not one fact that will standyoocriticism, if it is examined separately. It was toyoobreak down this terrible chain of facts, and to show that each piece ofyooevidence taken separately was unproved and fantastic, that I undertook theyoocase.”yooyooSo Fetyukovitch began.yooyoo“Gentlemen of the jury,” he suddenly protested, “I am new to thisyoodistrict. I have no preconceived ideas. The prisoner, a man of turbulentyooand unbridled temper, has not insulted me. Of course I recognize that the moral sentiment of localyoosociety is justly excited against him. The prisoner is of turbulent andyooviolent temper. Weyoohave, in the talented prosecutor’s speech, heard a stern analysis of theyooprisoner’s character and conduct, and his severe critical attitude to theyoocase was evident. And, what’s more, he went into psychological subtletiesyoointo which he could not have entered, if he had the least conscious andyoomalicious prejudice against the prisoner. It is worse if we are carried away by theyooartistic instinct, by the desire to create, so to speak, a romance,yooespecially if God has endowed us with psychological insight. Then he jumped back into the garden and spent five minutes overyoothe man, trying to discover whether he had killed him or not. And theyooprosecutor refuses to believe the prisoner’s statement that he ran to oldyooGrigory out of pity. ‘No,’ he says, ‘such sensibility is impossible atyoosuch a moment, that’s unnatural; he ran to find out whether the onlyyoowitness of his crime was dead or alive, and so showed that he hadyoocommitted the murder, since he would not have run back for any otheryooreason.’yooyoo“Here you have psychology; but let us take the same method and apply it toyoothe case the other way round, and our result will be no less probable. Theyoomurderer, we are told, leapt down to find out, as a precaution, whetheryoothe witness was alive or not, yet he had left in his murdered father’syoostudy, as the prosecutor himself argues, an amazing piece of evidence inyoothe shape of a torn envelope, with an inscription that there had beenyoothree thousand roubles in it. ‘If he had carried that envelope away withyoohim, no one in the world would have known of that envelope and of theyoonotes in it, and that the money had been stolen by the prisoner.’ Thoseyooare the prosecutor’s own words. So on one side you see a complete absenceyooof precaution, a man who has lost his head and run away in a fright,yooleaving that clew on the floor, and two minutes later, when he has killedyooanother man, we are entitled to assume the most heartless and calculatingyooforesight in him. But even admitting this was so, it is psychologicalyoosubtlety, I suppose, that discerns that under certain circumstances Iyoobecome as bloodthirsty and keen-sighted as a Caucasian eagle, while at theyoonext I am as timid and blind as a mole. But if I am so bloodthirsty andyoocruelly calculating that when I kill a man I only run back to find outyoowhether he is alive to witness against me, why should I spend five minutesyoolooking after my victim at the risk of encountering other witnesses? Whyyoosoak my handkerchief, wiping the blood off his head so that it may beyooevidence against me later? If he were so cold-hearted and calculating, whyyoonot hit the servant on the head again and again with the same pestle so asyooto kill him outright and relieve himself of all anxiety about the witness?yooyoo“Again, though he ran to see whether the witness was alive, he leftyooanother witness on the path, that brass pestle which he had taken from theyootwo women, and which they could always recognize afterwards as theirs, andyooprove that he had taken it from them. And it is not as though he hadyooforgotten it on the path, dropped it through carelessness or haste, no, heyoohad flung away his weapon, for it was found fifteen paces from whereyooGrigory lay. Why did he do so? Just because he was grieved at havingyookilled a man, an old servant; and he flung away the pestle with a curse,yooas a murderous weapon. That’s how it must have been, what other reasonyoocould he have had for throwing it so far? Had he murdered him, he would never have run toyooanother victim out of pity; then he would have felt differently; hisyoothoughts would have been centered on self-preservation. He would have hadyoonone to spare for pity, that is beyond doubt. On the contrary, he wouldyoohave broken his skull instead of spending five minutes looking after him.yooThere was room for pity and good-feeling just because his conscience hadyoobeen clear till then. Here we have a different psychology. I haveyoopurposely resorted to this method, gentlemen of the jury, to show that youyoocan prove anything by it. It all depends on who makes use of it.yooPsychology lures even most serious people into romancing, and quiteyoounconsciously. I am speaking of the abuse of psychology, gentlemen.”yooyooSounds of approval and laughter, at the expense of the prosecutor, wereyooagain audible in the court. I will not repeat the speech in detail; I willyooonly quote some passages from it, some leading points.yooyooyooyooChapter XI. There Was No Money. There Was No RobberyyooyooyooThere was one point that struck every one in Fetyukovitch’s speech. Heyooflatly denied the existence of the fatal three thousand roubles, andyooconsequently, the possibility of their having been stolen.yooyoo“Gentlemen of the jury,” he began. “Every new and unprejudiced observeryoomust be struck by a characteristic peculiarity in the present case,yoonamely, the charge of robbery, and the complete impossibility of provingyoothat there was anything to be stolen. And There Was No Murder Eitheryooyooyoo“Allow me, gentlemen of the jury, to remind you that a man’s life is atyoostake and that you must be careful. I made some inquiries: heyooresented his parentage, was ashamed of it, and would clench his teeth whenyoohe remembered that he was the son of ‘stinking Lizaveta.’ He wasyoodisrespectful to the servant Grigory and his wife, who had cared for himyooin his childhood. He cursed and jeered at Russia. He dreamed of going toyooFrance and becoming a Frenchman. He used often to say that he hadn’t theyoomeans to do so. I fancy he loved no one but himself and had a strangelyyoohigh opinion of himself. His conception of culture was limited to goodyooclothes, clean shirt-fronts and polished boots. Believing himself to beyoothe illegitimate son of Fyodor Pavlovitch (there is evidence of this), heyoomight well have resented his position, compared with that of his master’syoolegitimate sons. They had everything, he nothing. They had all the rights,yoothey had the inheritance, while he was only the cook. He told me himselfyoothat he had helped Fyodor Pavlovitch to put the notes in the envelope. Theyoodestination of that sum—a sum which would have made his career—must haveyoobeen hateful to him. Moreover, he saw three thousand roubles in newyoorainbow-colored notes. (I asked him about that on purpose.) Oh, beware ofyooshowing an ambitious and envious man a large sum of money at once! A Corrupter Of Thoughtyooyooyoo“It’s not only the accumulation of facts that threatens my client withyooruin, gentlemen of the jury,” he began, “what is really damning for myyooclient is one fact—the dead body of his father. The Peasants Stand FirmyooyooyooThis was how Fetyukovitch concluded his speech, and the enthusiasm of theyooaudience burst like an irresistible storm. Had we better come back here to-night?yooHe’ll be drunk, you know.”yooyoo“Perhaps he will. Let us come together, you and I, that will be enough, toyoospend an hour with them, with the mother and Nina. If we all come togetheryoowe shall remind them of everything again,” Alyosha suggested.yooyoo“The landlady is laying the table for them now—there’ll be a funeralyoodinner or something, the priest is coming; shall we go back to it,yooKaramazov?”yooyoo“Of course,” said Alyosha.yooyoo“It’s all so strange, Karamazov, such sorrow and then pancakes after it,yooit all seems so unnatural in our religion.”yooyoo“They are going to have salmon, too,” the boy who had discovered aboutyooTroy observed in a loud voice.yooyoo“I beg you most earnestly, Kartashov, not to interrupt again with youryooidiotic remarks, especially when one is not talking to you and doesn’tyoocare to know whether you exist or not!” Kolya snapped out irritably. Theyooboy flushed crimson but did not dare to reply.yooyooMeantime they were strolling slowly along the path and suddenly Smurovyooexclaimed:yooyoo“There’s Ilusha’s stone, under which they wanted to bury him.”yooyooThey all stood still by the big stone. Alyosha looked and the wholeyoopicture of what Snegiryov had described to him that day, how Ilusha,yooweeping and hugging his father, had cried, “Father, father, how heyooinsulted you,” rose at once before his imagination.yooyooA sudden impulse seemed to come into his soul. With a serious and earnestyooexpression he looked from one to another of the bright, pleasant faces ofyooIlusha’s schoolfellows, and suddenly said to them:yooyoo“Boys, I should like to say one word to you, here at this place.”yooyooThe boys stood round him and at once bent attentive and expectant eyesyooupon him.yooyoo“Boys, we shall soon part. I shall be for some time with my two brothers,yooof whom one is going to Siberia and the other is lying at death’s door.yooBut soon I shall leave this town, perhaps for a long time, so we shallyoopart. Let us make a compact here, at Ilusha’s stone, that we will neveryooforget Ilusha and one another. And whatever happens to us later in life,yooif we don’t meet for twenty years afterwards, let us always remember howyoowe buried the poor boy at whom we once threw stones, do you remember, byyoothe bridge? and afterwards we all grew so fond of him. He was a fine boy,yooa kind-hearted, brave boy, he felt for his father’s honor and resented theyoocruel insult to him and stood up for him. And so in the first place, weyoowill remember him, boys, all our lives. And even if we are occupied withyoomost important things, if we attain to honor or fall into greatyoomisfortune—still let us remember how good it was once here, when we wereyooall together, united by a good and kind feeling which made us, for theyootime we were loving that poor boy, better perhaps than we are. My littleyoodoves—let me call you so, for you are very like them, those pretty blueyoobirds, at this minute as I look at your good dear faces. My dear children,yooperhaps you won’t understand what I am saying to you, because I oftenyoospeak very unintelligibly, but you’ll remember it all the same and willyooagree with my words some time. You must know that there is nothing higheryooand stronger and more wholesome and good for life in the future than someyoogood memory, especially a memory of childhood, of home. People talk to youyooa great deal about your education, but some good, sacred memory, preservedyoofrom childhood, is perhaps the best education. If a man carries many suchyoomemories with him into life, he is safe to the end of his days, and if oneyoohas only one good memory left in one’s heart, even that may sometime beyoothe means of saving us. Perhaps we may even grow wicked later on, may beyoounable to refrain from a bad action, may laugh at men’s tears and at thoseyoopeople who say as Kolya did just now, ‘I want to suffer for all men,’ andyoomay even jeer spitefully at such people. But however bad we mayyoobecome—which God forbid—yet, when we recall how we buried Ilusha, how weyooloved him in his last days, and how we have been talking like friends allyootogether, at this stone, the cruelest and most mocking of us—if we doyoobecome so—will not dare to laugh inwardly at having been kind and good atyoothis moment! What’s more, perhaps, that one memory may keep him from greatyooevil and he will reflect and say, ‘Yes, I was good and brave and honestyoothen!’ Let him laugh to himself, that’s no matter, a man often laughs atyoowhat’s good and kind. That’s only from thoughtlessness. But I assure you,yooboys, that as he laughs he will say at once in his heart, ‘No, I do wrongyooto laugh, for that’s not a thing to laugh at.’ ”yooyoo“That will be so, I understand you, Karamazov!” cried Kolya, with flashingyooeyes.yooyooThe boys were excited and they, too, wanted to say something, but theyyoorestrained themselves, looking with intentness and emotion at the speaker.yooyoo“I say this in case we become bad,” Alyosha went on, “but there’s noyooreason why we should become bad, is there, boys? Let us be, first andyooabove all, kind, then honest and then let us never forget each other! Iyoosay that again. I give you my word for my part that I’ll never forget oneyooof you. Every face looking at me now I shall remember even for thirtyyooyears. Just now Kolya said to Kartashov that we did not care to knowyoowhether he exists or not. But I cannot forget that Kartashov exists andyoothat he is not blushing now as he did when he discovered the founders ofyooTroy, but is looking at me with his jolly, kind, dear little eyes. Boys,yoomy dear boys, let us all be generous and brave like Ilusha, clever, braveyooand generous like Kolya (though he will be ever so much cleverer when heyoois grown up), and let us all be as modest, as clever and sweet asyooKartashov. But why am I talking about those two? You are all dear to me,yooboys, from this day forth, I have a place in my heart for you all, and Iyoobeg you to keep a place in your hearts for me! Well, and who has united usyooin this kind, good feeling which we shall remember and intend to rememberyooall our lives? Who, if not Ilusha, the good boy, the dear boy, precious toyoous for ever! Let us never forget him. May his memory live for ever in ouryoohearts from this time forth!”yooyoo“Yes, yes, for ever, for ever!” the boys cried in their ringing voices,yoowith softened faces.yooyoo“Let us remember his face and his clothes and his poor little boots, hisyoocoffin and his unhappy, sinful father, and how boldly he stood up for himyooalone against the whole school.”yooyoo“We will remember, we will remember,” cried the boys. “He was brave, heyoowas good!”yooyoo“Ah, how I loved him!” exclaimed Kolya.yooyoo“Ah, children, ah, dear friends, don’t be afraid of life! How good life isyoowhen one does something good and just!”yooyoo“Yes, yes,” the boys repeated enthusiastically.yooyoo“Karamazov, we love you!” a voice, probably Kartashov’s, criedyooimpulsively.yooyoo“We love you, we love you!” they all caught it up. There were tears in theyooeyes of many of them.yooyoo“Hurrah for Karamazov!” Kolya shouted ecstatically.yooyoo“And may the dead boy’s memory live for ever!” Alyosha added again withyoofeeling.yooyoo“For ever!” the boys chimed in again.yooyoo“Karamazov,” cried Kolya, “can it be true what’s taught us in religion,yoothat we shall all rise again from the dead and shall live and see eachyooother again, all, Ilusha too?”yooyoo“Certainly we shall all rise again, certainly we shall see each other andyooshall tell each other with joy and gladness all that has happened!”yooAlyosha answered, half laughing, half enthusiastic.yooyoo“Ah, how splendid it will be!” broke from Kolya.yooyoo“Well, now we will finish talking and go to his funeral dinner. Don’t beyooput out at our eating pancakes—it’s a very old custom and there’syoosomething nice in that!” laughed Alyosha. “Well, let us go! And now we goyoohand in hand.”yooyoo“And always so, all our lives hand in hand! Hurrah for Karamazov!” Kolyayoocried once more rapturously, and once more the boys took up hisyooexclamation: “Hurrah for Karamazov!”yooyooTHE ENDyooyooyooyooyooyooyooFOOTNOTESyooyooyoo    1 In Russian, “silen.”yooyoo    2 A proverbial expression in Russia.yooyoo    3 Grushenka.yooyoo    4 i.e. setter dog.yooyoo    5 Probably the public event was the Decabrist plot against the Tsar,yoo      of December 1825, in which the most distinguished men in Russia wereyoo      concerned.—TRANSLATOR’S NOTE.yooyoo    6 When a monk’s body is carried out from the cell to the church andyoo      from the church to the graveyard, the canticle “What earthly joy...”yoo      is sung. The father and mother spent their eveningsyooin reading aloud to their children, generally from books of a seriousyoocharacter.yooyooThough always sickly and delicate Dostoevsky came out third in theyoofinal examination of the Petersburg school of Engineering. He was accused of "taking part in conversations againstyoothe censorship, of reading a letter from Byelinsky to Gogol, and ofyooknowing of the intention to set up a printing press." After eight months' imprisonmentyoohe was with twenty-one others taken out to the Semyonovsky Square toyoobe shot. Writing to his brother Mihail, Dostoevsky says: "They snappedyoowords over our heads, and they made us put on the white shirts worn byyoopersons condemned to death. The sentence was commuted to hard labour.yooyooOne of the prisoners, Grigoryev, went mad as soon as he was untied, andyoonever regained his sanity.yooyooThe intense suffering of this experience left a lasting stamp onyooDostoevsky's mind. Then followed four years of penalyooservitude, spent in the company of common criminals in Siberia, whereyoohe began the "Dead House," and some years of service in a disciplinaryyoobattalion.yooyooHe had shown signs of some obscure nervous disease before his arrestyooand this now developed into violent attacks of epilepsy, from which heyoosuffered for the rest of his life. He started a journal--"Vremya," which wasyooforbidden by the Censorship through a misunderstanding. In 1864 he lostyoohis first wife and his brother Mihail. He was in terrible poverty, yetyoohe took upon himself the payment of his brother's debts. He startedyooanother journal--"The Epoch," which within a few months was alsoyooprohibited. He was weighed down by debt, his brother's family wasyoodependent on him, he was forced to write at heart-breaking speed, and isyoosaid never to have corrected his work.
